This document provides comprehensive API documentation for the R/HOOD app's backend services, including Supabase database functions, authentication, and real-time subscriptions.

chunks.title: Base Configuration
chunks.text:

- **Platform**: Supabase (PostgreSQL + REST API)

chunks.text:
### Get User Connections
```javascript
// GET /rest/v1/connections?requester_id=eq.{userId}
const { data, error } = await supabase
  .from('connections')
  .select(`
    *,
    connected_user:user_profiles!connections_connected_user_id_fkey(
      id,
      dj_name,
      full_name,
      profile_image_url,
      city
    )
  `)
  .eq('requester_id', userId);
```

chunks.title: Update Connection Status
chunks.text:
### Update Connection Status
```javascript
// PATCH /rest/v1/connections?id=eq.{connectionId}
const { data, error } = await supabase
  .from('connections')
  .update({ connection_status: 'accepted' })
  .eq('id', connectionId)
  .select()
  .single();
```

### Messages

#### Send Message
```javascript
// POST /rest/v1/messages
const { data, error } = await supabase
  .from('messages')
  .insert({
    thread_id: threadId,
    sender_id: userId,
    content: messageContent,
    message_type: 'text'
  })
  .select()
  .single();
```

#### Get Messages for Thread
```javascript
// GET /rest/v1/messages?thread_id=eq.{threadId}
const { data, error } = await supabase
  .from('messages')
  .select(`
    *,
    sender:user_profiles!messages_sender_id_fkey(
      id,
      dj_name,
      full_name,
      profile_image_url
    )
  `)
  .eq('thread_id', threadId)
  .order('created_at', { ascending: true });
```

#### Send Multimedia Message
```javascript
// POST /rest/v1/messages
const { data, error } = await supabase
  .from('messages')
  .insert({
    thread_id: threadId,
    sender_id: userId,
    content: 'Image message',
    message_type: 'image',
    media_url: imageUrl,
    media_filename: 'image.jpg',
    media_size: fileSize,
    media_mime_type: 'image/jpeg'

  .single();
```

chunks.title: üçé Apple OAuth Setup Guide for R/HOOD
chunks.text: # üçé Apple OAuth Setup Guide for R/HOOD

chunks.title: Overview
chunks.text:
## Overview

This guide will help you set up full Apple OAuth for web-based Sign in with Apple. This is needed when native Apple Sign-In isn't available (like in older builds or Expo Go).

---

chunks.title: üìã What You Need
chunks.text:
## üìã What You Need

From Apple Developer Console:

1. **Team ID** (10 characters)
2. **Services ID** (Client ID)
3. **Key ID** (10 characters)
4. **Private Key** (.p8 file)

---

chunks.title: üîß Step-by-Step Setup
chunks.text: ## üîß Step-by-Step Setup

chunks.title: Step 1: Get Your Team ID
chunks.text:
### Step 1: Get Your Team ID

1. Go to: https://developer.apple.com/account
2. Look at the **top right corner** of the page
3. You'll see your **Team ID** (10 characters, like: `ABC1234DEF`)
4. **Copy and save it** - you'll need this for Supabase

---

chunks.title: Step 2: Create a Services ID
chunks.text:
### Step 2: Create a Services ID

1. Go to: https://developer.apple.com/account/resources/identifiers/list/serviceId
2. Click the **"+"** button (top left) to add a new identifier
3. Select **"Services IDs"** ‚Üí Click **"Continue"**
4. Fill in the form:
   - **Description**: `R/HOOD Sign In`
   - **Identifier**: `com.rhoodapp.mobile.signin`
5. Click **"Continue"** ‚Üí Click **"Register"**

> **Note:** The Services ID (`com.rhoodapp.mobile.signin`) is different from your app's bundle ID (`com.rhoodapp.mobile`). This is intentional!

---

chunks.title: Step 3: Configure the Services ID for Sign in with Apple
chunks.text:
### Step 3: Configure the Services ID for Sign in with Apple

1. In the Services IDs list, **click on** the Services ID you just created
2. Check the box for **"Sign in with Apple"** to enable it
3. Click **"Configure"** next to "Sign in with Apple"
4. In the configuration screen:
   - **Primary App ID**: Select `com.rhoodapp.mobile` (your app's bundle ID)
   - **Website URLs** section:
     - **Domains**: `jsmcduecuxtaqizhmiqo.supabase.co`
     - **Return URLs**: `https://jsmcduecuxtaqizhmiqo.supabase.co/auth/v1/callback`
5. Click **"Save"**
6. Click **"Continue"** ‚Üí Click **"Save"** again

---

chunks.title: Step 4: Create a Sign in with Apple Key
chunks.text:
### Step 4: Create a Sign in with Apple Key

1. Go to: https://developer.apple.com/account/resources/authkeys/list
2. Click the **"+"** button to create a new key
3. Fill in:
   - **Key Name**: `R/HOOD Sign in with Apple Key`
   - Check the box for **"Sign in with Apple"**
4. Click **"Configure"** next to "Sign in with Apple"
5. Select **Primary App ID**: `com.rhoodapp.mobile`
6. Click **"Save"**
7. Click **"Continue"**
8. Click **"Register"**
9. **Download the .p8 file** - you can only download this ONCE!
10. **Save the Key ID** (10 characters, like: `AB12CD34EF`)

> ‚ö†Ô∏è **IMPORTANT:** You can only download the .p8 file once! Save it somewhere safe.

---

chunks.title: Step 5: Convert .p8 Key to JWT Secret
chunks.text:
### Step 5: Convert .p8 Key to JWT Secret

The .p8 file needs to be converted to a JWT (JSON Web Token) format for Supabase.

#### Option A: Use Node.js Script (Recommended)

I'll create a script for you to convert the .p8 file:

1. Save your downloaded .p8 file to the project root (e.g., `AuthKey_AB12CD34EF.p8`)
2. Run the conversion script (I'll create this for you)
3. Copy the JWT output

#### Option B: Manual Conversion

If you prefer, you can use online tools or manual methods, but the script is safer.

---

chunks.title: Step 6: Add Credentials to Supabase
chunks.text:
### Step 6: Add Credentials to Supabase

1. Go to: https://supabase.com/dashboard/project/jsmcduecuxtaqizhmiqo/auth/providers
2. Click on **"Apple"**
3. Fill in the fields:
   - **Enable Sign in with Apple**: Toggle ON ‚úÖ
   - **Client IDs**: `com.rhoodapp.mobile.signin` (your Services ID)
   - **Team ID**: (Your 10-character Team ID from Step 1)
   - **Key ID**: (Your 10-character Key ID from Step 4)
   - **Secret Key**: (The JWT you generated in Step 5)
   - **Allow users without an email**: Toggle ON ‚úÖ (recommended)
4. Click **"Save"**

---

chunks.title: ‚úÖ Testing
chunks.text:
## ‚úÖ Testing

After setup:

1. Open your R/HOOD app in TestFlight
2. Tap **"Continue with Apple"**
3. Should open Safari browser with Apple Sign-In
4. Complete sign-in
5. Should redirect back to app successfully ‚úÖ

chunks.title: üêõ Troubleshooting
chunks.text: ## üêõ Troubleshooting

chunks.title: Error: "Unable to exchange external code"
chunks.text:
### Error: "Unable to exchange external code"

**Cause:** Client IDs don't match or credentials are incorrect  
**Fix:** Double-check all credentials in Supabase match Apple Developer Console

chunks.title: Error: "Sign in not completed"
chunks.text:
### Error: "Sign in not completed"

**Cause:** Redirect URL not configured correctly  
**Fix:** Verify the return URL in Services ID configuration matches Supabase callback URL exactly

chunks.title: Error: "Invalid client"
chunks.text:
### Error: "Invalid client"

**Cause:** Services ID not properly configured  
**Fix:** Make sure you enabled "Sign in with Apple" on the Services ID and configured it with your app's bundle ID

---

chunks.title: üìö Summary
chunks.text:
## üìö Summary

**What you configured:**

- ‚úÖ Team ID from Apple Developer account
- ‚úÖ Services ID (`com.rhoodapp.mobile.signin`) for web OAuth
- ‚úÖ Sign in with Apple Key (.p8 file)
- ‚úÖ JWT secret for Supabase
- ‚úÖ Supabase Apple provider with all credentials

**What this enables:**

- ‚úÖ Web-based Apple Sign-In (browser fallback)
- ‚úÖ Works in current TestFlight builds
- ‚úÖ Works alongside native Apple Sign-In (when available)

**Next steps:**

- Build v1.1.0 with native modules for better UX
- Native Apple Sign-In won't need browser popup
- Will show "R/HOOD" branding instead of Supabase domain

---

chunks.title: üîê Security Notes
chunks.text:
## üîê Security Notes

- **Never commit** the .p8 file to GitHub
- **Never commit** the JWT secret to GitHub
- Store these securely (password manager, encrypted storage)
- The .p8 file can only be downloaded once from Apple
- Keys can be revoked and regenerated if compromised

---

chunks.title: üìû Need Help?
chunks.text:
## üìû Need Help?

If you run into issues:

1. Check Apple Developer Console for any warnings
2. Verify all IDs match exactly (no typos)
3. Check Supabase logs for detailed error messages
4. Ensure return URL is exactly: `https://jsmcduecuxtaqizhmiqo.supabase.co/auth/v1/callback`

---

chunks.title: üçé Apple Sign-In Debug Guide
chunks.text: # üçé Apple Sign-In Debug Guide

chunks.title: üéØ Current Status
chunks.text:
## üéØ Current Status

Your R/HOOD app has **NATIVE Apple Sign-In** implemented using `expo-apple-authentication`. This is the recommended approach!

chunks.title: ‚úÖ What's Already Configured
chunks.text: ## ‚úÖ What's Already Configured

chunks.title: In Your App (`app.json`):
chunks.text:
### In Your App (`app.json`):

- ‚úÖ `bundleIdentifier`: `com.rhoodapp.mobile`
- ‚úÖ `usesAppleSignIn`: `true`
- ‚úÖ URL Scheme: `rhoodapp://`
- ‚úÖ Native implementation in `lib/supabase.js` (lines 268-318)

chunks.title: How It Works:
chunks.text:
### How It Works:

1. **Native Flow** (iOS device/TestFlight): Uses `AppleAuthentication.signInAsync()` ‚Üí `signInWithIdToken()`
2. **Web Fallback** (Expo Go/Simulator): Uses browser OAuth ‚Üí `signInWithAppleWeb()`

---

chunks.title: üêõ The Error You're Seeing
chunks.text:
## üêõ The Error You're Seeing

**Error**: "Unable to exchange external code for a Supabase session"

**What It Means**:

- Apple Sign-In is working on your app side ‚úÖ
- But Supabase can't verify the Apple token ‚ùå
- This happens when the Apple provider isn't properly enabled in Supabase

---

chunks.title: üîß How to Fix
chunks.text: ## üîß How to Fix

chunks.title: Step 1: Enable Apple Provider in Supabase
chunks.text:
### Step 1: Enable Apple Provider in Supabase

1. Go to your Supabase Dashboard:

   ```
   https://supabase.com/dashboard/project/jsmcduecuxtaqizhmiqo/auth/providers
   ```

2. Find "Apple" in the list of providers

3. Click to expand it

4. **Toggle "Enable Sign in with Apple" to ON**

5. **For Native Sign-In**: You don't need to fill in Services ID, Team ID, Key ID, or Secret Key!

   - These are only required for web-based OAuth
   - Native `signInWithIdToken` works without them

6. Click "Save"

chunks.title: Step 2: Verify Redirect URLs (Optional, for web fallback)
chunks.text:
### Step 2: Verify Redirect URLs (Optional, for web fallback)

If you also want the web fallback to work (for testing in Expo Go), add these to Supabase:

1. Go to: Authentication ‚Üí URL Configuration ‚Üí Redirect URLs
2. Add:
   - `rhoodapp://auth/callback`
   - `rhoodapp://*`
   - `exp://localhost:8081` (for Expo Go)

---

chunks.text: ## üÜò Common Issues

chunks.title: Issue 1: "Apple Sign-In is not available on this device"
chunks.text:
### Issue 1: "Apple Sign-In is not available on this device"

**Cause**: Testing on Android or simulator without Apple Sign-In capability
**Fix**: Test on a real iOS device

chunks.title: Issue 2: "Unable to exchange external code"
chunks.text:
### Issue 2: "Unable to exchange external code"

**Cause**: Apple provider not enabled in Supabase
**Fix**: Enable the Apple provider in Supabase (Step 1 above)

chunks.title: Issue 3: Browser opens with "localhost" error
chunks.text:
### Issue 3: Browser opens with "localhost" error

**Cause**: Web fallback triggered, but redirect URL not configured
**Fix**:

- Either: Add redirect URLs to Supabase (Step 2 above)
- Or: Use a development build instead of Expo Go for native sign-in

---

chunks.title: üéØ Recommended Setup
chunks.text:
## üéØ Recommended Setup

**For Production (Best User Experience):**

1. ‚úÖ Enable Apple provider in Supabase (toggle only, no keys needed)
2. ‚úÖ Use native Apple Sign-In (already implemented in your app)
3. ‚úÖ Build with EAS or `expo run:ios` (not Expo Go)
4. ‚úÖ Test on real iOS device or TestFlight

**Current Implementation:**

- Your app already has native Apple Sign-In ‚úÖ
- Just needs Supabase provider enabled ‚úÖ

---

chunks.title: üìû Next Steps
chunks.text:
## üìû Next Steps

1. **Enable Apple provider in Supabase** (5 seconds)
2. **Test in TestFlight** on iOS device
3. **Report back** if you see any errors

That's it! Native Apple Sign-In should work perfectly after Step 1.

chunks.title: üîç Debug Logs
chunks.text:
## üîç Debug Logs

If you're still having issues, check your console logs for:

```javascript
üçé Attempting native Apple Sign-In...
üîê Generated nonce: [nonce]
‚úÖ Apple credential received: true
‚úÖ Native Apple Sign-In successful: [email]
```

If you see:

```javascript
‚ùå Supabase Apple auth error: [error]
```

Then the issue is with Supabase configuration, not your app.

chunks.text: # üçé Apple Sign-In Implementation Guide

chunks.title: üìã Overview
chunks.text:
## üìã Overview

This document explains how Apple Sign-In is implemented in the R/HOOD app using a native-first `expo-apple-authentication` flow with an automatic Supabase OAuth fallback, both powered by `signInWithIdToken`.

---

chunks.title: üèóÔ∏è Architecture
chunks.text: ## üèóÔ∏è Architecture

chunks.title: Implementation Location
chunks.text:
### Implementation Location

- **File**: `lib/supabase.js`
- **Function**: `signInWithApple()`
- **Method**: Native implementation using `AppleAuthentication.signInAsync()` + `supabase.auth.signInWithIdToken()`

chunks.title: Why This Approach?
chunks.text:
### Why This Approach?

- ‚úÖ **Native Experience First**: Prioritises iOS native Apple Sign-In UI for the best UX
- ‚úÖ **Automatic Fallback**: Seamlessly falls back to Supabase OAuth when native sign-in is unavailable (simulator, Expo Go)
- ‚úÖ **Secure**: Uses nonce-based verification handled entirely by Supabase
- ‚úÖ **Production Ready**: Minimal logging, no debug prompts, no hard-coded secrets
- ‚úÖ **TestFlight & Development Friendly**: Works in production builds and continues to function during local Expo testing

---

chunks.title: üîê How It Works
chunks.text: ## üîê How It Works

chunks.title: The Nonce Flow
Why Two Different Nonces?
chunks.text:
### Why Two Different Nonces?

- **Apple receives**: `hashedNonce` (SHA256 hash of raw nonce, base64url encoded)
- **Supabase receives**: `rawNonce` (original hex string)
- **Supabase verifies**: It hashes the raw nonce and compares it to the nonce in Apple's ID token

This prevents man-in-the-middle attacks and ensures the token is fresh.

---

chunks.title: üõ†Ô∏è Configuration
chunks.text: ## üõ†Ô∏è Configuration

chunks.title: App Configuration (`app.json`)
Supabase Configuration
chunks.text:
### Supabase Configuration

1. **Enable Apple Provider**:

   - Go to: Supabase Dashboard ‚Üí Authentication ‚Üí Providers
   - Find "Apple" and toggle it **ON**

2. **Configuration Requirements**:

   - **Native flow** (`signInWithIdToken`): Services ID, Team ID, Key ID, and Secret Key are optional; Supabase validates against the bundle ID
   - **OAuth fallback** (`signInWithOAuth`): Requires the full Apple Services ID + Auth Key configuration so that Supabase can initiate the hosted web flow

3. **Bundle ID Must Match**:
   - Apple Developer Console: `com.rhoodapp.mobile`
   - app.json: `"bundleIdentifier": "com.rhoodapp.mobile"`
   - Supabase: Will validate against this bundle ID

### Key Features

1. **Native-First Flow**: Attempts `expo-apple-authentication` before anything else
2. **Automatic OAuth Fallback**: Transparently switches to Supabase-hosted OAuth when native sign-in isn't available (simulator, Expo Go, Android)
3. **Duplicate Tap Guard**: `_signingInWithApple` flag prevents concurrent attempts
4. **Clean Error Handling**: User cancellations bubble up cleanly, unexpected errors log once and reuse fallback

chunks.text: ## üß™ Testing

chunks.title: Where It Works
chunks.text:
### Where It Works

‚úÖ **Native flow (signInWithIdToken):**

- Physical iOS devices (iOS 13+) via TestFlight or production builds
- Development client builds that embed the native Apple module

‚ö†Ô∏è **OAuth fallback (signInWithOAuth):**

- Expo Go or iOS Simulator when the native module is unavailable
- Requires Apple provider to be fully configured in Supabase (Services ID, Team ID, Key ID, Secret)
- Best suited for internal testing‚Äîproduction users should rely on the native flow

‚ùå **Not supported:**

- Android devices (Apple Sign-In is iOS-only)
- Bare development mode without either the native module or a configured OAuth provider

chunks.text:
### Testing Checklist

- [ ] Testing on physical iOS device (iOS 13+)
- [ ] Using TestFlight or production build
- [ ] Apple provider enabled in Supabase
- [ ] Bundle ID matches in all places
- [ ] Device has Apple ID signed in

chunks.title: üîí Security
chunks.text: ## üîí Security

chunks.title: Nonce Security
chunks.text:
### Nonce Security

- **Random**: Generated using `Crypto.getRandomBytesAsync(32)` (cryptographically secure)
- **One-Time Use**: Fresh nonce for every sign-in attempt
- **Hashed**: Apple receives SHA256 hash, preventing raw nonce exposure
- **Verified**: Supabase validates the nonce matches Apple's token

chunks.title: Token Validation
chunks.text:
### Token Validation

Supabase automatically validates:

- ‚úÖ Token signature (signed by Apple)
- ‚úÖ Issuer (`iss`) is `https://appleid.apple.com`
- ‚úÖ Audience (`aud`) is `com.rhoodapp.mobile`
- ‚úÖ Nonce matches (SHA256 of raw nonce)
- ‚úÖ Token hasn't expired

chunks.title: üêõ Troubleshooting
chunks.text: ## üêõ Troubleshooting

chunks.title: Issue: "Nonces mismatch"
chunks.text:
### Issue: "Nonces mismatch"

**Causes:**

1. Using different raw nonce for Apple and Supabase
2. Not hashing the nonce correctly for Apple
3. Encoding issues (base64 vs base64url)

**Solution:**

- Ensure using the clean implementation above
- Always send **hashed** nonce to Apple, **raw** nonce to Supabase
- Use proper base64url encoding (replace `+` with `-`, `/` with `_`, remove `=`)

chunks.title: Issue: Works in development, fails in production
chunks.text:
### Issue: Works in development, fails in production

**Cause:** React Native production optimizations

**Solution:**

- Our implementation uses minimal state
- No refs or complex state management
- Clean async/await flow
- Should work identically in dev and prod

chunks.title: Issue: "Unable to exchange external code"
chunks.text:
### Issue: "Unable to exchange external code"

**Cause:** Apple provider not enabled in Supabase

**Solution:**

1. Go to Supabase Dashboard
2. Authentication ‚Üí Providers
3. Enable Apple provider
4. No additional configuration needed for native sign-in

chunks.title: Issue: OAuth fallback returns "Provider not configured"
chunks.text:
### Issue: OAuth fallback returns "Provider not configured"

**Cause:** Apple Services ID credentials are missing in Supabase, so the hosted OAuth flow cannot start.

**Solution:**

1. In Supabase Dashboard, open the Apple provider settings
2. Fill in the **Services ID**, **Team ID**, **Key ID**, and upload the **Auth Key (.p8)**
3. Add the redirect URLs generated by Supabase (e.g. `rhoodapp://auth/callback`) to your Apple developer configuration
4. Save changes, then retry the fallback flow

---

chunks.title: üéØ Best Practices
chunks.text: ## üéØ Best Practices

chunks.title: ‚úÖ Do:
chunks.text:
### ‚úÖ Do:

- Use native `AppleAuthentication.signInAsync()`
- Generate fresh nonce for each attempt
- Send hashed nonce to Apple, raw nonce to Supabase
- Test on physical iOS devices
- Handle errors gracefully
- Prevent double-tap with guard flag

chunks.title: ‚ùå Don't:
chunks.text:
### ‚ùå Don't:

- Use web-based OAuth in native apps
- Reuse nonces across sign-in attempts
- Send the same nonce to both Apple and Supabase
- Test in simulator (won't work)
- Add complex debugging in production code
- Skip availability check

---

chunks.title: üí° Key Takeaways
chunks.text:
## üí° Key Takeaways

1. **Nonce is critical**: Always use fresh, properly hashed nonces
2. **Native is better**: Use `signInWithIdToken` for native apps
3. **Test on device**: Simulator won't work
4. **Simple is better**: Clean implementation = fewer bugs
5. **Supabase handles validation**: Trust the platform

chunks.title: Audio Session Conflict Fix
chunks.text: # Audio Session Conflict Fix

chunks.title: Problem
chunks.text:
## Problem

Console logs showed this error:

```
AQIONode.cpp:590   client <RemoteIOClient@0x71bff3000(@0x71bff3240); output; CMSession(UserEventAgent[32], 0xffffffff)>: could not fetch audio session category (err = 1768843583)
```

chunks.title: Root Cause
chunks.text:
## Root Cause

**Audio session configuration conflict** on iOS:

- `react-native-track-player` manages the iOS audio session internally when `iosCategory: "playback"` is set in `updateOptions()`
- `lib/lockScreenControls.js` was ALSO calling `Audio.setAudioModeAsync()` from expo-av on iOS
- Having both frameworks try to configure the audio session causes iOS to fail with error code 1768843583

chunks.title: Solution
Why This Works
chunks.text:
## Why This Works

1. **On iOS with TrackPlayer:**

   - TrackPlayer's `iosCategory: "playback"` in `updateOptions()` sets up the audio session
   - No need for expo-av's `setAudioModeAsync()`
   - TrackPlayer is the single source of truth for audio session configuration

2. **On Android:**

   - expo-av is used for playback
   - `setAudioModeAsync()` is still needed for background playback

3. **Result:**
   - No conflicting audio session configurations
   - iOS audio session properly configured by TrackPlayer
   - No more "could not fetch audio session category" errors

chunks.title: Verification
chunks.text:
## Verification

After this fix, you should:

1. ‚úÖ No longer see `could not fetch audio session category` errors in Console
2. ‚úÖ See log: `üì± iOS: Audio session managed by react-native-track-player`
3. ‚úÖ Lock screen controls should work properly (no audio session conflicts)

chunks.title: Related Files
chunks.text:
## Related Files

- `lib/lockScreenControls.js` - Fixed to skip audio session config on iOS
- `src/audio/player.js` - TrackPlayer configures iOS audio session via `iosCategory: "playback"`
- `App.js` - Already correctly skips `setAudioModeAsync()` on iOS (early return)

chunks.title: What Each Setting Does
chunks.text: ## What Each Setting Does

chunks.title: UIBackgroundModes: ["audio"]
chunks.text:
### UIBackgroundModes: ["audio"]

- **What it does:** Tells iOS the app needs to continue running in the background for audio playback
- **Why it's needed:** Without this, iOS will suspend the app when it goes to background
- **Effect:** App can play audio even when screen is locked or app is in background
- **Result:** ‚úÖ Lock screen controls can appear and function

chunks.title: AVAudioSessionCategory: "playback"
chunks.text:
### AVAudioSessionCategory: "playback"

- **What it does:** Configures the audio session to prioritize playback
- **Why it's needed:** Ensures audio continues in silent mode and when screen locks
- **Effect:** Audio plays even when:
  - Device is locked
  - Silent switch is on
  - App is in background
- **Result:** ‚úÖ Audio session configured for background playback

chunks.title: AVAudioSessionMode: "default"
chunks.text:
### AVAudioSessionMode: "default"

- **What it does:** Sets the default playback mode
- **Why it's needed:** Standard mode for music/media playback
- **Effect:** Standard audio playback behavior
- **Result:** ‚úÖ Compatible with remote controls

chunks.title: Important Notes
chunks.text: ## Important Notes

chunks.title: ‚ö†Ô∏è TrackPlayer vs app.json Configuration
chunks.text:
### ‚ö†Ô∏è TrackPlayer vs app.json Configuration

**Important:** When using `react-native-track-player`, the library ALSO sets the audio session category via:

```javascript
TrackPlayer.updateOptions({
  iosCategory: "playback", // This also sets AVAudioSessionCategory
});
```

**This is OK because:**

- ‚úÖ TrackPlayer's `iosCategory` matches `app.json`'s `AVAudioSessionCategory`
- ‚úÖ Both are set to `"playback"`
- ‚úÖ No conflict - they're setting the same value

**However:** If there was a mismatch, it could cause issues.

chunks.text:

1. **app.json** ‚Üí Expo reads `infoPlist` settings
2. **Build time** ‚Üí Expo writes to `ios/RHOOD/Info.plist`
3. **Runtime** ‚Üí iOS reads `Info.plist` for permissions/capabilities
4. **TrackPlayer** ‚Üí Also sets audio session category programmatically (matches Info.plist)

chunks.title: Complete Guide: iOS Lock Screen Remote Controls
chunks.text: # Complete Guide: iOS Lock Screen Remote Controls

chunks.title: Overview
chunks.text:
## Overview

For lock screen remote controls to work on iOS, you need **both**:

1. **The UI to appear** (lock screen showing media info)
2. **The buttons to function** (play/pause/next/prev actually control playback)

This guide covers **ALL** the steps required and how they must work together.

---

chunks.title: ‚úÖ Complete Checklist (Must Have ALL of These)
chunks.text: ## ‚úÖ Complete Checklist (Must Have ALL of These)

chunks.title: 1. Service Registration (App Startup) ‚úÖ
chunks.text:
### 1. Service Registration (App Startup) ‚úÖ

**File:** `index.js`

- ‚úÖ `TrackPlayer.registerPlaybackService()` called at app startup
- ‚úÖ Must be called **BEFORE** React mounts
- ‚úÖ Must be called **BEFORE** any audio plays
- ‚úÖ Service function must export correctly from `src/audio/playbackService.js`

**What it does:** Tells iOS where to send remote control events (lock screen button presses)

---

chunks.title: 2. Background Modes (App Configuration) ‚úÖ
chunks.text:
### 2. Background Modes (App Configuration) ‚úÖ

**File:** `app.json` ‚Üí `ios.infoPlist`

- ‚úÖ `UIBackgroundModes: ["audio"]` - Allows background playback
- ‚úÖ `AVAudioSessionCategory: "playback"` - Sets audio session category
- ‚úÖ `AVAudioSessionMode: "default"` - Sets audio session mode

**What it does:** iOS permission to play audio in background

---

chunks.title: 3. Playback Service Event Handlers ‚úÖ
chunks.text:
### 3. Playback Service Event Handlers ‚úÖ

**File:** `src/audio/playbackService.js`

- ‚úÖ Service function registered and exports correctly
- ‚úÖ `Event.RemotePlay` handler calls `TrackPlayer.play()`
- ‚úÖ `Event.RemotePause` handler calls `TrackPlayer.pause()`
- ‚úÖ `Event.RemoteNext` handler calls `TrackPlayer.skipToNext()` or App.js callback
- ‚úÖ `Event.RemotePrevious` handler calls `TrackPlayer.skipToPrevious()` or App.js callback
- ‚úÖ `Event.RemoteSeek` handler calls `TrackPlayer.seekTo()`

**What it does:** Handles button presses from lock screen/Control Center

---

chunks.title: 4. Player Initialization ‚úÖ
chunks.text:
### 4. Player Initialization ‚úÖ

**File:** `src/audio/player.js`

- ‚úÖ `TrackPlayer.setupPlayer()` called (triggers service function)
- ‚úÖ `TrackPlayer.updateOptions()` called with:
  - ‚úÖ `capabilities: [Play, Pause, SkipToNext, SkipToPrevious, SeekTo, ...]`
  - ‚úÖ `compactCapabilities: [Play, Pause, SkipToNext]`
  - ‚úÖ `iosCategory: "playback"` - **CRITICAL** for remote controls

**What it does:** Tells iOS which buttons to show and enables remote control routing

---

chunks.title: 5. Track Metadata ‚úÖ
chunks.text:
### 5. Track Metadata ‚úÖ

**When calling `playTrack()`:**

- ‚úÖ `id` - Unique track identifier
- ‚úÖ `url` - HTTPS audio URL (can be stream)
- ‚úÖ `title` - Track title (shows on lock screen)
- ‚úÖ `artist` - Artist name (shows on lock screen)
- ‚úÖ `artwork` - HTTPS image URL, square, ‚â•1024px (optional but recommended)
- ‚úÖ `duration` - Duration in seconds (optional, needed for scrubber)

**What it does:** Lock screen displays this metadata

---

chunks.title: 6. Initialization Order (CRITICAL) ‚úÖ
chunks.text:
### 6. Initialization Order (CRITICAL) ‚úÖ

The **EXACT** order must be:

```
1. App Starts
   ‚Üì
2. index.js: TrackPlayer.registerPlaybackService()  ‚Üê Service registered
   ‚Üì
3. React Mounts ‚Üí App.js loads
   ‚Üì
4. setupGlobalAudio() called
   ‚Üì
5. trackPlayer.setupPlayer() called
   ‚Üì
6. TrackPlayer.setupPlayer() internally calls playbackService() function
   ‚Üì
7. playbackService() registers ALL event listeners (RemotePlay, RemotePause, etc.)
   ‚Üì
8. setupPlayer() continues ‚Üí TrackPlayer.updateOptions() called with capabilities
   ‚Üì
9. iOS sees capabilities + registered listeners ‚Üí Enables remote controls
   ‚Üì
10. playTrack() called ‚Üí Track added and starts playing
   ‚Üì
11. iOS recognizes playback ‚Üí Shows lock screen UI with buttons
   ‚Üì
12. User presses button ‚Üí iOS routes to playbackService handlers ‚Üí Works! ‚úÖ
```

---

chunks.title: üîç Are There Conflicts Between In-App and Out-of-App Audio?
chunks.text: ## üîç Are There Conflicts Between In-App and Out-of-App Audio?

chunks.title: **YES - There WAS a conflict (now fixed):**
chunks.text:
### **YES - There WAS a conflict (now fixed):**

#### Conflict #1: Audio Session Configuration (FIXED ‚úÖ)

**Problem:**

- TrackPlayer sets audio session via `iosCategory: "playback"` in `updateOptions()`
- `lib/lockScreenControls.js` was ALSO calling `Audio.setAudioModeAsync()` on iOS
- **Result:** Audio session conflict ‚Üí `could not fetch audio session category` error

**Fix:**

- `lockScreenControls.js` now skips `setAudioModeAsync()` on iOS
- TrackPlayer exclusively manages iOS audio session
- ‚úÖ Fixed in commit `32526f1`

#### Conflict #2: expo-av vs TrackPlayer (HANDLED ‚úÖ)

**Current Status:**

- ‚úÖ iOS: Uses **ONLY** TrackPlayer (expo-av not used for global audio)
- ‚úÖ Android: Uses expo-av (TrackPlayer not used)
- ‚úÖ No overlap - each platform uses its own system

**In `App.js` `playGlobalAudio()`:**

```javascript
if (Platform.OS === "ios") {
  // Use ONLY track-player - expo-av is NOT called
  await trackPlayer.playTrack({...});
  return; // Early return - no expo-av code runs
}

// Android only
await Audio.setAudioModeAsync({...}); // Only on Android
```

---

chunks.text: ## ‚ùå Common Failure Points

**Symptom:** Lock screen shows generic/blank info
**Check:** Verify track has `title`, `artist`, `artwork`
**Fix:** Pass complete metadata to `playTrack()`

chunks.title: 7. Wrong Initialization Order
chunks.text:
### 7. Wrong Initialization Order

**Symptom:** Everything looks right but buttons still don't work
**Check:** Verify order: service registration ‚Üí setupPlayer ‚Üí updateOptions ‚Üí play
**Fix:** Follow exact order in checklist above

chunks.title: ListenScreen.js
chunks.text:
### ListenScreen.js
**Purpose**: Main music discovery and playback interface

**Key Features**:
- Audio mix browsing and playback
- Search functionality with genre filtering
- Queue management
- Background audio controls
- Progressive image loading for mix artwork

**Props**:
```javascript
{
  globalAudioState: Object,    // Current audio playback state
  onPlayAudio: Function,       // Audio play handler
  onPauseAudio: Function,      // Audio pause handler
  onResumeAudio: Function,     // Audio resume handler
  onStopAudio: Function,       // Audio stop handler
  onAddToQueue: Function,      // Add to queue handler
  onPlayNext: Function,        // Play next handler
  onClearQueue: Function,      // Clear queue handler
  onNavigate: Function,        // Navigation handler
  user: Object                 // Current user data
}
```

**Key Functions**:
- `fetchMixes()`: Loads mixes from database
- `handlePlayMix(mix)`: Initiates audio playback
- `handleSearch(query)`: Filters mixes by search query
- `loadMoreMixes()`: Pagination for mix loading

**Usage Example**:

chunks.title: ‚ö†Ô∏è Important: Ignore Identity Services Errors
chunks.text:
## ‚ö†Ô∏è Important: Ignore Identity Services Errors

If you see this error in Console:

```
Error Domain=com.apple.identityservices.error Code=3 "Remote user isn't registered"
```

**This is NOT related to audio remote controls!** This is Apple's Identity Services (iMessage/FaceTime) system trying to send a message. It's harmless and unrelated to our audio playback.

chunks.title: ‚úÖ What to Actually Look For
chunks.text: ## ‚úÖ What to Actually Look For

chunks.title: Filter by These Markers in Console.app:
chunks.text:
### Filter by These Markers in Console.app:

1. **`[STARTUP]`** - Service registration at app launch
2. **`[SERVICE]`** - Playback service initialization and handler attachment
3. **`[PLAYER]`** - TrackPlayer setup and capability configuration
4. **`[REMOTE]`** - **CRITICAL**: Lock screen button presses

chunks.title: Expected Log Sequence When Working:
chunks.text:
### Expected Log Sequence When Working:

#### At App Launch:

```
[STARTUP] ‚úÖ Track player playback service registered at app startup
[STARTUP] üì± iOS will now send remote control events to this service
[SERVICE] üéµ Background playback service initializing...
[SERVICE] ‚úÖ TrackPlayer instance verified
[SERVICE] ‚úÖ Event listeners attached successfully
[PLAYER] üéµ Initializing react-native-track-player...
[PLAYER] ‚úÖ TrackPlayer.setupPlayer() completed
[PLAYER] ‚öôÔ∏è Configuring TrackPlayer capabilities...
[PLAYER] ‚úÖ Track player capabilities configured for remote control events
```

#### When You Press Lock Screen Buttons:

```
üîµüîµüîµ [REMOTE] PLAY button pressed on lock screen/Control Center
‚úÖ‚úÖ‚úÖ [REMOTE] Play executed successfully
```

OR

```
‚è∏Ô∏è‚è∏Ô∏è‚è∏Ô∏è [REMOTE] PAUSE button pressed on lock screen/Control Center
‚úÖ‚úÖ‚úÖ [REMOTE] Pause executed successfully
```

chunks.title: How to Filter in Console.app
chunks.text: ## How to Filter in Console.app

chunks.title: Step 1: Connect iPhone to Mac
chunks.text:
### Step 1: Connect iPhone to Mac

- Connect via USB cable
- Open Console.app (Applications ‚Üí Utilities ‚Üí Console)

chunks.title: Step 2: Select Your Device
chunks.text:

chunks.title: Step 3: Filter Logs
chunks.text:
### Step 3: Filter Logs

In the search box at top right, type:

- **`[REMOTE]`** - See all remote button presses
- **`[SERVICE]`** - See service registration and setup
- **`[STARTUP]`** - See app startup registration

chunks.text:

chunks.title: Troubleshooting
chunks.text: ## Troubleshooting

chunks.title: If You See `[STARTUP]` but NOT `[REMOTE]`:
chunks.text:
### If You See `[STARTUP]` but NOT `[REMOTE]`:

- ‚úÖ Service registered correctly
- ‚ùå Buttons aren't triggering events
- **Possible causes:**
  - Capabilities not set correctly
  - Audio session conflict
  - TrackPlayer not properly initialized

chunks.title: If You See `[REMOTE]` logs but audio doesn't change:
chunks.text:
### If You See `[REMOTE]` logs but audio doesn't change:

- ‚úÖ Events are reaching handlers
- ‚ùå But playback isn't responding
- **Possible causes:**
  - TrackPlayer state mismatch
  - Queue issues
  - Error in playback command

chunks.title: If You Don't See ANY `[REMOTE]` logs:
chunks.text:
### If You Don't See ANY `[REMOTE]` logs:

- ‚ùå Events aren't reaching the service
- **Possible causes:**
  - Service not registered properly
  - Capabilities not enabled
  - Expo-av still active (audio session conflict)

chunks.title: Ignore These (Harmless) Logs
chunks.text:
## Ignore These (Harmless) Logs

- ‚úÖ Identity Services errors (com.apple.identityservices.error)
- ‚úÖ SpringBoard logs (lock screen UI rendering)
- ‚úÖ RunningBoard logs (process management)
- ‚úÖ AudioAccessory logs (unless specifically about your app)

Focus only on logs with `[STARTUP]`, `[SERVICE]`, `[PLAYER]`, or `[REMOTE]` prefixes.

## üóÑÔ∏è Overview

The R/HOOD app uses Supabase (PostgreSQL) as its backend database. This document provides comprehensive documentation of the database schema, relationships, and API functions.

chunks.title: üèóÔ∏è Database Architecture
chunks.text: ## üèóÔ∏è Database Architecture

chunks.text:
### Technology Stack
- **Database**: PostgreSQL (via Supabase)
- **Authentication**: Supabase Auth with JWT
- **Real-time**: Supabase Realtime subscriptions
- **Security**: Row Level Security (RLS) policies
- **Storage**: Supabase Storage for files

---

chunks.title: üìä Core Tables
chunks.text: ## üìä Core Tables

chunks.title: user_profiles
chunks.text:
### user_profiles
**Purpose**: Store DJ and user profile information

```sql
CREATE TABLE user_profiles (
  id UUID PRIMARY KEY DEFAULT gen_random_uuid(),
  email VARCHAR(255) UNIQUE NOT NULL,
  dj_name VARCHAR(100),
  full_name VARCHAR(255),
  first_name VARCHAR(100),
  last_name VARCHAR(100),
  bio TEXT,
  status_message TEXT,
  location VARCHAR(255),
  city VARCHAR(100),
  country VARCHAR(100),
  instagram VARCHAR(255),
  soundcloud VARCHAR(255),
  genres TEXT[], -- Array of genre strings
  profile_image_url TEXT,
  is_verified BOOLEAN DEFAULT false,
  is_public BOOLEAN DEFAULT true,
```

chunks.text: ## üîê Row Level Security (RLS)

chunks.title: Security Policies
chunks.text:
### Security Policies

#### user_profiles
```sql
-- Users can view their own profile and public profiles
CREATE POLICY "Users can view profiles" ON user_profiles
  FOR SELECT USING (
    auth.uid() = id OR is_public = true
  );

-- Users can update their own profile
CREATE POLICY "Users can update own profile" ON user_profiles
  FOR UPDATE USING (auth.uid() = id);

-- Users can insert their own profile
CREATE POLICY "Users can insert own profile" ON user_profiles
  FOR INSERT WITH CHECK (auth.uid() = id);
```

#### connections
```sql
-- Users can view their own connections
CREATE POLICY "Users can view own connections" ON connections
  FOR SELECT USING (
    auth.uid() = requester_id OR auth.uid() = connected_user_id
  );

-- Users can create connection requests
CREATE POLICY "Users can create connections" ON connections
  FOR INSERT WITH CHECK (auth.uid() = requester_id);

-- Users can update their own connections
CREATE POLICY "Users can update own connections" ON connections
  FOR UPDATE USING (
    auth.uid() = requester_id OR auth.uid() = connected_user_id
  );
```

#### messages
```sql
-- Users can view messages in their threads
CREATE POLICY "Users can view thread messages"

chunks.title: Security Policies
chunks.text:
ON messages
  FOR SELECT USING (
    EXISTS (
      SELECT 1 FROM message_threads mt
      WHERE mt.id = messages.thread_id
      AND (mt.user_id_1 = auth.uid() OR mt.user_id_2 = auth.uid())
    )
  );

-- Users can insert messages in their threads
CREATE POLICY "Users can insert messages" ON messages
  FOR INSERT WITH CHECK (
    auth.uid() = sender_id AND
    EXISTS (
      SELECT 1 FROM message_threads mt
      WHERE mt.id = messages.thread_id
      AND (mt.user_id_1 = auth.uid() OR mt.user_id_2 = auth.uid())
    )
  );
```

#### mixes
```sql
-- Users can view public mixes and their own mixes
CREATE POLICY "Users can view mixes" ON mixes
  FOR SELECT USING (
    auth.uid() = user_id OR is_public = true
  );

-- Users can insert their own mixes
CREATE POLICY "Users can insert own mixes" ON mixes
  FOR INSERT WITH CHECK (auth.uid() = user_id);

-- Users can update their own mixes
CREATE POLICY "Users can update own mixes" ON mixes
  FOR UPDATE USING (auth.uid() = user_id);
```

chunks.title: 1Ô∏è‚É£ Check Console Logs
chunks.text:
### 1Ô∏è‚É£ Check Console Logs

**Look for these patterns:**

**‚úÖ GOOD - Messages Loading:**

```
üßµ Using thread ID: abc123...
```

**‚ùå BAD - No Messages Found:**

**‚úÖ GOOD - Message Sent Successfully:**
```
‚úÖ Individual message sent successfully!

  id: 'msg-456', 
  thread_id: 'abc123', 
  sender_id: 'user-789',
```

```
  details: null 
}
```

**Action**: RLS policy issue. Run `database/fix-all-messaging-rls.sql`.

chunks.title: 3Ô∏è‚É£ Run SQL Test
chunks.text:
### 3Ô∏è‚É£ Run SQL Test

In Supabase SQL Editor, run `database/test-messages-quick.sql`.

**Expected output:**
```
=== RECENT MESSAGE THREADS ===
id                                  | type       | user_id_1 | user_id_2 | created_at
------------------------------------|------------|-----------|-----------|------------------
abc-123-def-456                     | individual | user-1    | user-2    | 2024-01-15 10:30
...

----------|------------------------------|-----------|------------------|------------------
```

chunks.title: 4Ô∏è‚É£ Common Issues & Fixes
chunks.text:
### 4Ô∏è‚É£ Common Issues & Fixes

#### Issue: "permission denied for table messages"
**Cause**: RLS policy blocking insert/select
**Fix**: Run `database/fix-all-messaging-rls.sql`

#### Issue: Messages in database but not showing in app
**Cause**: Thread ID mismatch or RLS blocking SELECT
**Fix**: 
1. Check that console shows correct thread ID
2. Verify RLS policies allow SELECT
3. Check `thread_id` matches between INSERT and SELECT

#### Issue: Messages disappearing after sending
**Cause**: Real-time subscription not working or thread mismatch
**Fix**:
1. Check console for "üì® New individual message received" logs
2. Verify thread ID is consistent
3. Run `database/cleanup-duplicate-threads.sql`

#### Issue: "Invalid input syntax for type uuid"
**Cause**: User ID or DJ ID not valid UUIDs
**Fix**: Check console logs for user IDs being passed

- **128 kbps**: Good quality, smaller files
- **192 kbps**: High quality, balanced size
- **320 kbps**: Maximum quality, larger files

```bash

chunks.title: Convert to 192kbps MP3
chunks.text:
# Convert to 192kbps MP3
ffmpeg -i input.mp3 -b:a 192k output.mp3
```

Remove unnecessary silence at beginning/end:

```bash
ffmpeg -i input.mp3 -af silenceremove=1:0:-50dB output.mp3
```

```bash
ffmpeg -i input.mp3 -af "compand" output.mp3
```

chunks.title: Final Remote Controls Check - All Issues Fixed
chunks.text: # Final Remote Controls Check - All Issues Fixed

chunks.title: Summary
chunks.text:
## Summary
This document lists all potential issues that were identified and fixed to ensure iOS lock screen remote controls work correctly.

chunks.title: Issues Found and Fixed
chunks.text: ## Issues Found and Fixed

chunks.title: ‚úÖ 1. Early `setupPlayer()` Call Removed
chunks.text:
### ‚úÖ 1. Early `setupPlayer()` Call Removed
**Problem:**
- `setupGlobalAudio()` was calling `setupPlayer()` at app startup
- This happened before audio was actually needed
- Could cause timing issues with service registration

**Fix:**
- Removed early `setupPlayer()` call from `setupGlobalAudio()`
- Player now initializes lazily when `playTrack()` is called
- Ensures proper initialization order:
  1. Service registered at app startup (index.js)
  2. Player initialized when first track plays
  3. Service function runs and registers handlers
  4. Capabilities set via updateOptions()

**File:** `App.js` (line ~810)

---

chunks.title: ‚úÖ 2. Redundant `setupPlayer()` Call Removed
chunks.text:
### ‚úÖ 2. Redundant `setupPlayer()` Call Removed
**Problem:**
- `App.js` was calling `setupPlayer()` directly before `playTrack()`
- `playTrack()` also calls `setupPlayer()` internally
- Double initialization could cause timing issues

**Fix:**
- Removed redundant call from `App.js`
- `playTrack()` handles initialization internally

**File:** `App.js` (line ~1009)

---

chunks.title: ‚úÖ 3. Audio Session Configuration Conflict
chunks.text:
### ‚úÖ 3. Audio Session Configuration Conflict
**Problem:**
- `app.json` had `AVAudioSessionCategory: "playback"`
- TrackPlayer also sets this via `iosCategory: "playback"`
- Timing conflicts could prevent proper audio session setup

**Fix:**
- Removed `AVAudioSessionCategory` and `AVAudioSessionMode` from `app.json`
- TrackPlayer now exclusively manages audio session

**File:** `app.json` (lines 25-26)

---

chunks.title: ‚úÖ 4. Insufficient Delay After Service Registration
chunks.text:
### ‚úÖ 4. Insufficient Delay After Service Registration
**Problem:**
- 100ms delay was too short for native bridge to process service registration
- Event listeners might not be fully registered before `updateOptions()` is called

**Fix:**
- Increased delay from 100ms to 250ms
- Gives native bridge more time to process everything

**File:** `src/audio/player.js` (line ~89)

---

chunks.title: ‚úÖ 5. Multiple `updateOptions()` Calls
chunks.text:
### ‚úÖ 5. Multiple `updateOptions()` Calls
**Problem:**
- `updateOptions()` was called twice (capabilities, then progress interval)
- Second call might overwrite or conflict with first

**Fix:**
- Combined into single `updateOptions()` call
- All options set together

**File:** `src/audio/player.js` (lines 99-147)

---

chunks.title: ‚úÖ 6. Missing Error Handling
chunks.text:
### ‚úÖ 6. Missing Error Handling
**Problem:**
- `updateOptions()` failures weren't being caught
- Silent failures could prevent native handlers from being registered

**Fix:**
- Added comprehensive try-catch around `updateOptions()`
- Detailed error logging

**File:** `src/audio/player.js` (lines 102-147)

---

chunks.title: Initialization Order (Correct)
chunks.text:
## Initialization Order (Correct)

```
1. App Starts
   ‚Üì
2. index.js: TrackPlayer.registerPlaybackService() ‚Üê Service registered
   ‚Üì
3. React Mounts ‚Üí App.js loads
   ‚Üì
4. User plays audio ‚Üí playGlobalAudio() called
   ‚Üì
5. playTrack() called ‚Üí setupPlayer() called internally
   ‚Üì
6. TrackPlayer.setupPlayer() ‚Üí triggers playbackService() function
   ‚Üì
7. playbackService() registers ALL event listeners (synchronously)
   ‚Üì
8. 250ms delay ‚Üí native bridge processes registrations
   ‚Üì
9. updateOptions() called ‚Üí native handlers registered with iOS
   ‚Üì
10. Track added and starts playing
   ‚Üì
11. iOS shows lock screen UI with buttons
   ‚Üì
12. User presses button ‚Üí iOS routes to handlers ‚Üí Works! ‚úÖ
```

4. `src/audio/playbackService.js` - Enhanced logging

This document explains the gigs tracking and achievements system implemented in R/HOOD.

chunks.title: üìä Gigs Table
chunks.text: ## üìä Gigs Table

chunks.title: Purpose
chunks.text:
### Purpose
Track DJ performances, bookings, and completed events to build a performance history.

chunks.title: Schema
chunks.text:
### Schema

```sql
gigs
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ id (UUID)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ dj_id (UUID) ‚Üí user_profiles.id
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ opportunity_id (UUID) ‚Üí opportunities.id
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ name (VARCHAR) - Event name
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ venue (VARCHAR) - Venue name
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ location (VARCHAR) - City/address
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ event_date (DATE)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ start_time (TIME)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ end_time (TIME)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ payment (DECIMAL) - Payment amount
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ currency (VARCHAR) - Default 'GBP'
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ payment_status (ENUM) - pending/paid/cancelled
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ status (ENUM) - upcoming/completed/cancelled/in_progress
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ dj_rating (DECIMAL 0.0-5.0) - Venue's rating of DJ
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ venue_rating (DECIMAL 0.0-5.0) - DJ's rating of venue
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ description (TEXT)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ genre (VARCHAR)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ audience_size (INTEGER)

```

chunks.title: Automatic Updates
chunks.text:
### Automatic Updates

**When a gig is marked as completed:**
1. ‚úÖ Increments user's `gigs_completed` counter
2. ‚úÖ Updates user's average `rating` based on all completed gig ratings
3. ‚úÖ Sets `completed_at` timestamp
4. ‚úÖ Triggers achievement checks

Profile Integration
chunks.text:
### Profile Integration

Gigs appear in the "Recent Gigs" section of user profiles:

- Automatically loads from database

chunks.title: üèÜ Achievements System
chunks.text: ## üèÜ Achievements System

chunks.title: Purpose
chunks.text:
### Purpose
Gamify the platform by rewarding users for milestones and accomplishments.

chunks.title: Schema
chunks.text:
### Schema

**achievements** - Master list of available achievements
```sql
achievements
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ id (UUID)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ name (VARCHAR) - e.g., "First Gig"
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ description (TEXT)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ icon (VARCHAR) - Ionicons name
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ category (VARCHAR) - gigs/ratings/social/milestones
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ requirement_type (VARCHAR) - What to track
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ requirement_value (INTEGER) - Threshold value
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ credits_reward (INTEGER) - Credits awarded
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ sort_order (INTEGER)
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ is_active (BOOLEAN)
```

**user_achievements** - Tracks which users earned which achievements
```sql
user_achievements
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ id (UUID)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ user_id (UUID) ‚Üí user_profiles.id
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ achievement_id (UUID) ‚Üí achievements.id
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ earned (BOOLEAN)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ progress (INTEGER)
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ earned_at (TIMESTAMP)
```

chunks.title: Automatic Award System
Database Function
chunks.text:
### Database Function

The system includes a `check_and_award_achievements()` function that:
1. ‚úÖ Reads user stats (gigs_completed, rating, etc.)
2. ‚úÖ Checks against achievement requirements
3. ‚úÖ Awards new achievements automatically
4. ‚úÖ Prevents duplicate awards
5. ‚úÖ Awards credits to user

chunks.title: Profile Integration
chunks.text:
### Profile Integration

Achievements appear in the "Achievements" section of user profiles:
- Shows up to 4 featured achievements
- Displays earned status (colored icon vs gray)
- Automatically loads from database
- Updates in real-time when earned

chunks.text: ## üåä Audio Waveform Generation

chunks.title: Purpose
chunks.text:
### Purpose
Generate visual waveform representations for audio mixes displayed on profiles.

chunks.title: Features
Genre Profiles
chunks.text:
### Genre Profiles

Each genre has unique waveform characteristics:

- **House/Techno**: High intensity, buildups, drops
- **R&B/Soul**: Moderate intensity, smooth variations
- **Drum & Bass**: Very high intensity, rapid changes
- **Hip-Hop**: Medium intensity, rhythmic patterns

chunks.title: Google Sign-In Setup Guide (Simple OAuth)
chunks.text:
# Google Sign-In Setup Guide (Simple OAuth)

This is a clean, simple Google Sign-In implementation using Supabase OAuth.

chunks.title: ‚úÖ What's Implemented
chunks.text:
## ‚úÖ What's Implemented

- **OAuth-based Google Sign-In** (no native modules)
- **Works in Expo Go** (no development build needed)
- **Simple token extraction** from callback URL
- **Minimal complexity** (just ~80 lines of code)

chunks.title: üìã Setup Steps
chunks.text: ## üìã Setup Steps

chunks.title: 1. Google Cloud Console
chunks.text:
### 1. Google Cloud Console

You should already have OAuth credentials set up. If not:

1. Go to [Google Cloud Console](https://console.cloud.google.com/)
2. Select your project (or create one)
3. Navigate to **APIs & Services** ‚Üí **Credentials**
4. Create **OAuth 2.0 Client ID** (Web application type)
5. Add these **Authorized redirect URIs**:
   ```
   https://jsmcduecuxtaqizhmiqo.supabase.co/auth/v1/callback
   ```

**Current Credentials:**

- Web Client ID: `668336115926-vm1sb48m9q6cfg3he33t4f074e28s49m.apps.googleusercontent.com`
- Client Secret: (stored in Supabase)

chunks.title: 2. Supabase Configuration
chunks.text:
### 2. Supabase Configuration

1. Go to your [Supabase Dashboard](https://supabase.com/dashboard)
2. Navigate to **Authentication** ‚Üí **Providers**
3. Find **Google** and click **Edit**
4. Enable the provider
5. Add your credentials:
   - **Client ID**: Your Web Client ID from Google
   - **Client Secret**: Your Web Client Secret from Google
6. Add these **Redirect URLs**:
   ```
   rhoodapp://auth/callback
   rhoodapp://*
   exp://localhost:8081
   ```

chunks.title: 3. Test the Implementation
chunks.text:
### 3. Test the Implementation

1. Open your app in Expo Go
2. Tap "Continue with Google"
3. Complete sign-in in the browser
4. Should redirect back to the app
5. Check logs for success messages

chunks.title: üîç How It Works
chunks.text:
## üîç How It Works

1. **User taps "Continue with Google"**
2. **App calls `auth.signInWithGoogle()`**
3. **Supabase generates OAuth URL**
4. **Browser opens for authentication**
5. **User signs in with Google**
6. **Google redirects to Supabase with code**
7. **Supabase exchanges code for tokens**
8. **Supabase redirects to `rhoodapp://auth/callback` with tokens**
9. **App extracts tokens from URL**
10. **App creates session with `setSession()`**
11. **User is signed in!**

chunks.text:

chunks.text: ## ‚ùå Troubleshooting

chunks.text:

chunks.title: "No access token received" error
chunks.text:

chunks.text:

chunks.title: How to View iOS App Logs
chunks.text: # How to View iOS App Logs

chunks.title: ‚ö†Ô∏è IMPORTANT: Where JavaScript Logs Appear
chunks.text:
## ‚ö†Ô∏è IMPORTANT: Where JavaScript Logs Appear

**JavaScript `console.log()` messages (like `[STARTUP]`, `[SERVICE]`, `[REMOTE]`, `[PLAYER]`) will NOT appear in Console.app!**

**Console.app only shows system-level logs** (audio session state, app lifecycle, etc.)

**To see JavaScript logs, use:**

- **Xcode Console** (Method 2) - Best for native builds on physical devices
- **Metro Bundler** (Method 1) - Best for development builds

---

chunks.title: Quick Reference
chunks.text: ## Quick Reference

chunks.title: For Development (Metro Bundler)
chunks.text:
### For Development (Metro Bundler)

**Easiest method** - Logs appear in the terminal where you ran `npm start` or `expo start`

Look for:

- `[STARTUP]` - Service registration
- `[SERVICE]` - Service execution and handler registration
- `[REMOTE]` - Button presses on lock screen
- `[PLAYER]` - TrackPlayer initialization

---

chunks.title: Method 1: Metro Bundler Console (Recommended for Development)
chunks.text:
## Method 1: Metro Bundler Console (Recommended for Development)

**When to use:** Running app via `expo start` or `npm start`

1. Start your app:

   ```bash
   npm start
   # or
   expo start
   ```

2. Logs will appear in the same terminal window
3. Look for the log prefixes: `[STARTUP]`, `[SERVICE]`, `[REMOTE]`, `[PLAYER]`

**Note:** Some native logs (especially from the background service) might not appear here. For those, use Xcode Console.

---

chunks.title: Method 2: Xcode Console (Best for Native Builds & TestFlight)
chunks.text:
## Method 2: Xcode Console (Best for Native Builds & TestFlight)

**When to use:** Testing on physical device (including TestFlight builds) or need to see ALL logs including background service

chunks.title: For Physical Device (Including TestFlight):
chunks.text:
### For Physical Device (Including TestFlight):

**‚úÖ YES - Xcode Console works for TestFlight builds!**

1. **Connect your iPhone/iPad** via USB
2. **Open Xcode** (any version - you don't need to build from it)
3. **Window ‚Üí Devices and Simulators** (or press `Cmd+Shift+2`)
4. **Select your device** from the left sidebar
5. **Click "Open Console"** button (or "View Device Logs")
6. **Filter logs:**
   - In the search box at the top, type: `rhoodapp` or `com.rhoodapp.mobile`
   - Or search for: `[STARTUP]`, `[SERVICE]`, `[REMOTE]`, `[PLAYER]`
   - Or filter by process: Select your app from the process dropdown (if available)

**Important for TestFlight:**

- You **DO NOT** need to build from Xcode
- You **DO NOT** need to have the project open
- Just connect your device and open the console
- JavaScript logs (`[STARTUP]`, `[SERVICE]`, `[REMOTE]`, `[PLAYER]`) **WILL appear** here
- System logs (like "undeliverable command") will also appear here

chunks.title: For Simulator:
chunks.text:
### For Simulator:

1. **Open Xcode**
2. **Run your app** from Xcode (or have it running)
3. **View ‚Üí Debug Area ‚Üí Activate Console** (or press `Cmd+Shift+Y`)
4. Logs will appear in the bottom panel

**Tip:** You can filter by typing in the search box at the bottom of the console

chunks.title: üîç If You Don't See `[REMOTE]` Logs:
chunks.text:
### üîç If You Don't See `[REMOTE]` Logs:

- **Problem:** iOS isn't routing remote control events to handlers
- **Possible causes:**
  - Service not registered correctly
  - Handlers not registered before capabilities set
  - Audio session conflict
- **Check:** Look for `[STARTUP]` and `[SERVICE]` logs first

chunks.title: üîç If You See `[REMOTE]` Logs But Buttons Don't Work:
chunks.text:
### üîç If You See `[REMOTE]` Logs But Buttons Don't Work:

- **Problem:** Handlers are being called, but TrackPlayer methods are failing
- **Check:** Look for error messages after `[REMOTE]` logs
- **Example:**
  ```
  üîµüîµüîµ [REMOTE] PLAY button pressed
  ‚ùå‚ùå‚ùå [REMOTE] Play error: TrackPlayer not ready
  ```

chunks.title: Troubleshooting
chunks.text: ## Troubleshooting

chunks.title: "I don't see any logs"
chunks.text:
### "I don't see any logs"

1. **Check you're looking in the right place:**

   - Metro bundler = terminal where you ran `npm start`
   - Xcode Console = Xcode ‚Üí Devices ‚Üí Open Console
   - Terminal = separate terminal window with `xcrun simctl` command

2. **Check app is actually running:**

   - Make sure the app is launched and playing audio
   - Service logs only appear when `setupPlayer()` is called

3. **Check log level:**
   - Some log viewers filter by level
   - Make sure debug/info logs are enabled

- **Common causes:**
  - Service function not being called (check for `[STARTUP]` logs)

chunks.title: "I see MediaRemoteUI suspension messages"
chunks.text:
### "I see MediaRemoteUI suspension messages"

**Problem:** If you see logs like:

```
[osservice<com.apple.MediaRemoteUI>:91747] Suspending task
Sending stop command to com.apple.MediaRemoteUI
```

This means iOS is suspending the media remote UI service, which prevents lock screen controls from working.

**Solutions:**

1. **Verify background audio is enabled:**

   - Check `app.json` has `"UIBackgroundModes": ["audio"]`
   - Rebuild the app after changing this

2. **Ensure audio session is configured:**

   - The app should set `AVAudioSessionCategory` to `playback` before playing audio
   - `react-native-track-player` should handle this automatically

3. **Check for audio session conflicts:**

   - Make sure you're not using both `expo-av` and `react-native-track-player` simultaneously on iOS
   - iOS should use ONLY `react-native-track-player` for native controls

4. **Rebuild the app:**
   - Background modes require a native rebuild
   - Run `eas build --platform ios` or rebuild locally

# iOS Remote Controls Setup Verification

This document verifies that all requirements for iOS remote control events are correctly configured.

chunks.title: ‚úÖ Configuration Checklist
chunks.text: ## ‚úÖ Configuration Checklist

chunks.title: 1. Service Registration (index.js)
chunks.text:
### 1. Service Registration (index.js)

- ‚úÖ Service registered at app startup: `TrackPlayer.registerPlaybackService()` in `index.js`
- ‚úÖ Registered BEFORE any audio plays
- ‚úÖ Service function exported from `src/audio/playbackService.js`

**Status:** CORRECT ‚úÖ

chunks.title: 2. Background Modes (app.json)
chunks.text:
### 2. Background Modes (app.json)

- ‚úÖ `UIBackgroundModes: ["audio"]` configured
- ‚úÖ `AVAudioSessionCategory: "playback"` configured
- ‚úÖ `AVAudioSessionMode: "default"` configured

**Status:** CORRECT ‚úÖ

chunks.title: 3. Service Function (playbackService.js)
chunks.text:
### 3. Service Function (playbackService.js)

- ‚úÖ All remote event listeners registered INSIDE the service function
- ‚úÖ Listeners registered before `updateOptions()` is called
- ‚úÖ Service verifies TrackPlayer instance is available
- ‚úÖ Handles: RemotePlay, RemotePause, RemoteNext, RemotePrevious, RemoteSeek, RemoteStop

**Status:** CORRECT ‚úÖ

chunks.title: 4. Player Setup (player.js)
chunks.text:
### 4. Player Setup (player.js)

- ‚úÖ `setupPlayer()` calls `TrackPlayer.setupPlayer()` first
- ‚úÖ Waits 500ms for service to register listeners
- ‚úÖ Then calls `updateOptions()` with capabilities
- ‚úÖ Sets `iosCategory: "playback"`
- ‚úÖ Configures all required capabilities (Play, Pause, Next, Previous, Seek, etc.)

**Status:** CORRECT ‚úÖ

chunks.title: 5. Initialization Order
chunks.text:
### 5. Initialization Order

The correct order is now:

1. ‚úÖ App starts ‚Üí `index.js` registers service
2. ‚úÖ `setupGlobalAudio()` called ‚Üí waits for service, then calls `setupPlayer()`
3. ‚úÖ `setupPlayer()` ‚Üí calls `TrackPlayer.setupPlayer()` (triggers service function)
4. ‚úÖ Service function ‚Üí registers all remote event listeners
5. ‚úÖ `setupPlayer()` ‚Üí waits 500ms for service to finish
6. ‚úÖ `setupPlayer()` ‚Üí calls `updateOptions()` with capabilities
7. ‚úÖ Audio plays ‚Üí iOS recognizes app as "Now Playing" and sends remote events

**Status:** CORRECT ‚úÖ

chunks.title: üîç How to Verify It's Working
chunks.text:
## üîç How to Verify It's Working

1. **Build and run on a physical iOS device** (simulator won't work)

2. **Check console logs for this sequence:**

   ```
   ‚úÖ Track player playback service registered at app startup
   üéµ Initializing react-native-track-player...
   ‚úÖ TrackPlayer.setupPlayer() completed
   üéµ Playback service initializing...
   ‚úÖ Background playback service started
   üì± Registering remote control event listeners for iOS...
   ‚è≥ Waiting for playback service to register listeners...
   ‚úÖ Service listeners should now be registered
   ‚öôÔ∏è Configuring TrackPlayer capabilities...
   ‚úÖ Track player capabilities configured for remote control events
   ‚úÖ Track player initialized with capabilities
   ```

3. **Play audio and verify:**

   - Lock screen shows controls with artwork, title, artist
   - Control Center shows controls
   - AirPods controls work
   - Car Bluetooth controls work
   - Lock screen buttons (play/pause/next/prev) work

4. **Check for remote control events:**
   When you press buttons, you should see:
   ```
   üéµüîµ REMOTE PLAY BUTTON PRESSED
   üéµ Current state before play: [state]
   ‚úÖ Remote: Play command executed
   ```

chunks.title: üêõ Troubleshooting
chunks.text:
## üêõ Troubleshooting

If remote controls still don't work:

1. **Service not registering:** Check that `index.js` logs show "‚úÖ Track player playback service registered"
2. **Listeners not registering:** Check that `playbackService.js` logs show "‚úÖ Playback service event listeners registered"
3. **Capabilities not set:** Check that `setupPlayer()` completes without errors
4. **Timing issues:** The 500ms delay should be enough, but if not, increase it
5. **Physical device required:** Remote controls don't work in simulator - must test on real device

chunks.title: üìù Notes
chunks.text:
## üìù Notes

- The service function is called automatically when `TrackPlayer.setupPlayer()` is invoked
- The 500ms delay in `setupPlayer()` ensures the service has time to register listeners before capabilities are set
- iOS only sends remote control events to the app that is currently "Now Playing"
- All listeners are registered inside the service function (required by react-native-track-player)

chunks.title: üì® R/HOOD Peer-to-Peer Messaging Flow
chunks.text: # üì® R/HOOD Peer-to-Peer Messaging Flow

chunks.title: Overview
chunks.text:
## Overview

This document describes the complete peer-to-peer messaging flow in the R/HOOD app, from connection requests to sending messages.

---

chunks.title: üîó Connection Request Flow
chunks.text: ## üîó Connection Request Flow

chunks.title: 1. User Sends Connection Request
chunks.text:
### 1. User Sends Connection Request

**When:** User taps "Connect" on another DJ's profile

**What Happens:**

- `handleConnect()` is called (in `UserProfileView.js` or `ConnectionsScreen.js`)
- `db.createConnection(targetUserId)` is invoked
- Uses `create_connection_request` RPC function (fallback to direct INSERT)
- Creates entry in `connections` table with `status = 'pending'`

**Database:**

```sql
INSERT INTO connections (user_id_1, user_id_2, status, initiated_by)
VALUES (smaller_id, larger_id, 'pending', requester_id)
```

chunks.title: 2. Target User Receives Notification
chunks.text:
### 2. Target User Receives Notification

**What Happens:**

- Database trigger `notify_connection_request()` fires automatically
- Creates notification for the target user
- Shows "New Connection Request" with sender's name

**Notification:**

```sql
INSERT INTO notifications (user_id, title, message, type, related_id)
VALUES (target_user_id, 'New Connection Request', 'sender_name wants to connect with you', 'connection_request', connection_id)
```

**UI:**

- User sees notification in NotificationsScreen
- Badge count increases
- Alert shows in notification list

chunks.title: 3. User Accepts Connection
chunks.text:
### 3. User Accepts Connection

**When:** User taps "Accept" on the connection request notification

**What Happens:**

- `handleAcceptConnection()` is called
- `db.acceptConnection(connectionId)` is invoked
- Uses `accept_connection_request` RPC function
- Updates `connections` table: `status = 'accepted'`

**Database:**

```sql
UPDATE connections
SET status = 'accepted', accepted_at = NOW()
WHERE id = connection_id
```

chunks.title: 4. Original Requester Gets Notification
chunks.text:
### 4. Original Requester Gets Notification

**What Happens:**

- Database trigger `notify_connection_accepted()` fires automatically
- Creates notification for the original requester
- Shows "Connection Accepted" message

**Notification:**

```sql
INSERT INTO notifications (user_id, title, message, type, related_id)
VALUES (original_requester_id, 'Connection Accepted', 'accepter_name accepted your connection request', 'connection_accepted', connection_id)
```

chunks.title: 5. Success Modal Appears (Accepter Side)
chunks.text:
### 5. Success Modal Appears (Accepter Side)

**What Happens:**

- `setAcceptedUser()` is called with sender info
- `setShowAcceptModal(true)` displays modal
- Modal shows: "Connection Accepted!" with checkmark icon

**Modal Options:**

- **"Start Chatting"** button ‚Üí Navigates directly to messages screen
- **"Close"** button ‚Üí Dismisses modal

---

chunks.title: üí¨ Messaging Flow
chunks.text: ## üí¨ Messaging Flow

chunks.title: 1. Opening Chat
chunks.text:
### 1. Opening Chat

**When:** User taps "Start Chatting" from modal or opens from connections list

**What Happens:**

- `MessagesScreen` loads with `djId` and `chatType='individual'`
- `loadMessages()` checks connection status
- If connected: loads all messages from database
- If not connected: shows "Connect to start messaging" prompt

**Database Query:**

```javascript
// Get or create message thread
const threadId = await db.findOrCreateIndividualMessageThread(user.id, djId);

// Load messages
const messages = await db.getMessages(threadId);
```

chunks.title: 2. Sending a Message
chunks.text:
### 2. Sending a Message

**When:** User types message and taps send button

**What Happens:**

- `sendMessage()` is called
- Validates connection status (must be accepted)
- Gets/creates message thread
- Inserts message into `messages` table
- Adds message to UI immediately (optimistic update)
- Scrolled to bottom to show new message

**Database Insert:**

```javascript
await supabase.from("messages").insert({
  thread_id: threadId,
  sender_id: user.id,
  content: messageText,
  message_type: "text",
});
```

chunks.title: 3. Receiver Gets Notification
chunks.text:
### 3. Receiver Gets Notification

**What Happens:**

- Database trigger `notify_new_message()` fires automatically
- Gets receiver from `message_threads` table (other participant)
- Creates notification for receiver
- Shows preview of message

**Notification:**

```sql
INSERT INTO notifications (user_id, title, message, type, related_id)
VALUES (receiver_id, 'New Message', 'sender_name: message_preview', 'message', message_id)
```

chunks.title: 4. Real-time Message Delivery
chunks.text:
### 4. Real-time Message Delivery

**What Happens:**

- Supabase Realtime subscription on `messages` table
- When new message inserted, `onReceiveMessage()` callback fires
- Message immediately appears in chat for receiver
- Auto-scrolls to bottom

**Subscription:**

```javascript
supabase
  .channel(`messages-${threadId}`)
  .on("postgres_changes", { event: "INSERT", table: "messages" }, callback);
```

---

chunks.title: üóÑÔ∏è Database Schema
chunks.text: ## üóÑÔ∏è Database Schema

chunks.title: connections
chunks.text:
### connections

```sql
CREATE TABLE connections (
  id UUID PRIMARY KEY,
  user_id_1 UUID,
  user_id_2 UUID,
  status VARCHAR(20), -- 'pending', 'accepted', 'rejected'
  initiated_by UUID,
  created_at TIMESTAMP,
  accepted_at TIMESTAMP
);
```

chunks.title: message_threads
chunks.text:
### message_threads

```sql
CREATE TABLE message_threads (
  id UUID PRIMARY KEY,
  type VARCHAR(20), -- 'individual' or 'group'
  user_id_1 UUID,
  user_id_2 UUID,
  created_at TIMESTAMP,
  updated_at TIMESTAMP
);
```

chunks.title: messages
chunks.text:
### messages

```sql
CREATE TABLE messages (
  id UUID PRIMARY KEY,
  thread_id UUID REFERENCES message_threads(id),
  sender_id UUID,
  content TEXT,
  message_type VARCHAR(20), -- 'text', 'image', 'audio', 'file'
  media_url TEXT,
  created_at TIMESTAMP
);
```

chunks.title: notifications
chunks.text:
### notifications

```sql
CREATE TABLE notifications (
  id UUID PRIMARY KEY,
  user_id UUID,
  title VARCHAR(255),
  message TEXT,
  type VARCHAR(50),
  related_id UUID,
  is_read BOOLEAN DEFAULT false,
  created_at TIMESTAMP
);
```

---

chunks.title: üîî Notification Types
chunks.text:
## üîî Notification Types

1. **`connection_request`** - "User wants to connect with you"
2. **`connection_accepted`** - "User accepted your connection request"
3. **`message`** - "User: message preview"

chunks.title: ‚úÖ Complete Flow Summary
chunks.text:
## ‚úÖ Complete Flow Summary

1. ‚úÖ **User A sends connection request** ‚Üí Creates `connections` entry (pending)
2. ‚úÖ **User B receives notification** ‚Üí "User A wants to connect"

8. ‚úÖ **User B gets notification** ‚Üí "User A: message preview"
9. ‚úÖ **Real-time delivery** ‚Üí Message appears instantly in chat
10. ‚úÖ **All messages stored** ‚Üí Retrieved from database on load

chunks.title: Messaging Persistence Issue - Fix Guide
chunks.text: # Messaging Persistence Issue - Fix Guide

chunks.title: üêõ Problem
chunks.text:
## üêõ Problem

Messages are not persisting when sent from the app. The issue is likely related to Row Level Security (RLS) policies on the `messages` table that are out of sync with the current database schema.

chunks.title: üîç Root Cause
chunks.text:
## üîç Root Cause

The `messages` table was originally created with a `receiver_id` column, but the current implementation uses a `thread_id` approach for organizing messages. The RLS policies may still be referencing the old `receiver_id` column, or they may not exist at all.

Additionally, there may be a schema mismatch in the `message_threads` table:
- **Production schema**: Uses `user_id_1` and `user_id_2` columns
- **Legacy schema**: Uses `participant_1` and `participant_2` columns

chunks.title: ‚úÖ Solution
chunks.text:
## ‚úÖ Solution

Run the comprehensive fix script in your Supabase SQL Editor:

**File**: `database/fix-all-messaging-rls.sql`

This script will:

1. ‚úÖ Check the current table structures
2. ‚úÖ Add any missing columns (`thread_id`, `message_type`, multimedia fields)
3. ‚úÖ Drop all old RLS policies on the `messages` table
4. ‚úÖ Create new RLS policies that work with your current schema (automatically detects `user_id` vs `participant` columns)
5. ‚úÖ Update the notification trigger to work with both schemas

# Mix Artwork Flow Documentation

Complete guide for understanding and updating mix artwork images throughout the R/HOOD app.

chunks.title: üìä Overview
chunks.text:
## üìä Overview

Mix artwork images are:

1. **Stored**: In Supabase Storage `mixes` bucket
2. **Referenced**: Via `artwork_url` field in the `mixes` database table
3. **Associated**: One artwork per mix (1:1 relationship)
4. **Optional**: Mixes can exist without artwork

chunks.title: üóÑÔ∏è Database Structure
chunks.text: ## üóÑÔ∏è Database Structure

chunks.title: `mixes` Table Schema
chunks.text:
### `mixes` Table Schema

```sql
CREATE TABLE mixes (
  id UUID PRIMARY KEY DEFAULT gen_random_uuid(),
  user_id UUID REFERENCES user_profiles(id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
  title VARCHAR(255) NOT NULL,
  description TEXT,
  genre VARCHAR(100),
  duration INTEGER,
  file_url TEXT NOT NULL,           -- Audio file URL
  file_name VARCHAR(255),
  file_size BIGINT,
  artwork_url TEXT,                  -- ‚Üê IMAGE URL STORED HERE
  play_count INTEGER DEFAULT 0,
  likes_count INTEGER DEFAULT 0,
  is_public BOOLEAN DEFAULT true,
  created_at TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE DEFAULT NOW(),
  updated_at TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE DEFAULT NOW()
);
```

chunks.title: Key Field: `artwork_url`
chunks.text:
### Key Field: `artwork_url`

- **Type**: `TEXT` (nullable)
- **Content**: Full public URL to the image
- **Format**: `https://{project}.supabase.co/storage/v1/object/public/mixes/{user_id}/{filename}`
- **Example**: `https://xyz.supabase.co/storage/v1/object/public/mixes/abc123/artwork_1704067200.jpg`

chunks.title: Common Issues
chunks.text:
### Common Issues

#### 1. **Image Not Displaying**

**Possible Causes**:

- `artwork_url` is `NULL` or empty string
- URL is incorrect or broken
- Storage bucket permissions issue
- CORS or CDN issue

**Debug Query**:

```sql
SELECT
  id,
  title,
  artwork_url,
  LENGTH(artwork_url) as url_length
FROM mixes
WHERE id = 'your-mix-id';
```

#### 2. **Image Returns 404**

**Possible Causes**:

- File was deleted from storage
- Path is incorrect
- Bucket permissions changed

**Fix**:

```sql
-- Check if URL exists
SELECT artwork_url
FROM mixes
WHERE id = 'your-mix-id';

-- Then verify in Supabase Storage dashboard
```

#### 3. **Wrong Image Associated**

**Possible Causes**:

- Database update didn't complete
- Multiple artwork files in storage

**Fix**:

```sql
-- Verify current artwork_url
SELECT id, title, artwork_url
FROM mixes
WHERE id = 'your-mix-id';

-- Update if needed
UPDATE mixes
SET artwork_url = 'correct-url-here'
WHERE id = 'your-mix-id';
```

The `mixes` table has RLS enabled with policies:

1. **View Policy**: Users can see their own mixes + all public mixes
2. **Insert Policy**: Users can only upload mixes for themselves
3. **Update Policy**: Users can only update their own mixes
4. **Delete Policy**: Users can only delete their own mixes

2. **View**: Anyone can view mixes (public bucket)
3. **Update/Delete**: Users can only modify their own files

chunks.title: 1. Google OAuth Setup
chunks.text: ## 1. Google OAuth Setup

chunks.title: Step 1: Create Google OAuth Credentials
chunks.text:
### Step 1: Create Google OAuth Credentials

1. Go to [Google Cloud Console](https://console.cloud.google.com/)
2. Create a new project or select existing one
3. Enable the Google+ API
4. Go to "Credentials" ‚Üí "Create Credentials" ‚Üí "OAuth 2.0 Client IDs"
5. Create credentials for:
   - **iOS**: Bundle ID: `com.rhoodapp.mobile`
   - **Android**: Package name: `com.rhoodapp.mobile`
   - **Web**: For development

chunks.title: Step 2: Configure Supabase
chunks.text:
### Step 2: Configure Supabase

1. Go to your Supabase project dashboard
2. Navigate to Authentication ‚Üí Providers
3. Enable Google provider
4. Add your Google OAuth credentials:
   - **Client ID**: From Google Cloud Console
   - **Client Secret**: From Google Cloud Console
5. Set redirect URL: `https://jsmcduecuxtaqizhmiqo.supabase.co/auth/v1/callback`

chunks.title: Step 3: Configure Redirect URLs
chunks.text:
### Step 3: Configure Redirect URLs

Add these URLs to your Google OAuth configuration:

- `https://jsmcduecuxtaqizhmiqo.supabase.co/auth/v1/callback`
- `rhoodapp://auth/callback`

chunks.title: 2. Apple OAuth Setup
chunks.text: ## 2. Apple OAuth Setup

chunks.title: Step 1: Configure Apple Sign In
chunks.text:
### Step 1: Configure Apple Sign In

1. Go to [Apple Developer Console](https://developer.apple.com/)
2. Navigate to "Certificates, Identifiers & Profiles"
3. Select your App ID (`com.rhoodapp.mobile`)
4. Enable "Sign In with Apple" capability
5. Create a Service ID for web authentication

chunks.title: Step 2: Configure Supabase
chunks.text:
### Step 2: Configure Supabase

1. In Supabase dashboard ‚Üí Authentication ‚Üí Providers
2. Enable Apple provider
3. Add your Apple credentials:
   - **Client ID**: Your Service ID
   - **Client Secret**: Generated JWT token
4. Set redirect URL: `https://jsmcduecuxtaqizhmiqo.supabase.co/auth/v1/callback`

chunks.title: Step 3: Generate Apple Client Secret
chunks.text:
### Step 3: Generate Apple Client Secret

You'll need to generate a JWT token for Apple. Use this script:

```bash

chunks.title: Install jwt-cli

# Install jwt-cli
npm install -g jwt-cli

chunks.title: Generate the secret (replace with your actual values)
chunks.text:
# Generate the secret (replace with your actual values)
jwt encode \
  --secret "YOUR_APPLE_PRIVATE_KEY" \
  --iss "YOUR_TEAM_ID" \
  --sub "YOUR_SERVICE_ID" \
  --aud "https://appleid.apple.com" \
  --exp "+1y"
```
