chunks.title: OpenAI Edge Function Setup Guide
chunks.text:
# OpenAI Edge Function Setup Guide

This guide explains how to set up the secure OpenAI proxy using Supabase Edge Functions.

chunks.title: Why Use Edge Functions?
chunks.text:
## Why Use Edge Functions?

- ‚úÖ **Security**: API key stays on the server, never exposed to client
- ‚úÖ **Cost Control**: Can add rate limiting and usage tracking
- ‚úÖ **Reliability**: Centralized error handling and logging
- ‚úÖ **Scalability**: Supabase handles infrastructure

chunks.title: Quick Setup
chunks.text: ## Quick Setup

chunks.title: 1. Install Supabase CLI
chunks.text:
### 1. Install Supabase CLI

```bash
npm install -g supabase
```

chunks.title: 2. Login and Link Project
chunks.text:
### 2. Login and Link Project

```bash
supabase login
supabase link --project-ref YOUR_PROJECT_REF
```

Find your project ref in your Supabase Dashboard URL: `https://app.supabase.com/project/YOUR_PROJECT_REF`

chunks.title: 3. Set OpenAI API Key as Secret
chunks.text:
### 3. Set OpenAI API Key as Secret

**Via CLI:**
```bash
supabase secrets set OPENAI_API_KEY=sk-proj-...
```

**Via Dashboard:**
1. Go to **Project Settings** ‚Üí **Edge Functions** ‚Üí **Secrets**
2. Add `OPENAI_API_KEY` with your OpenAI API key value
3. (Optional) Add `OPENAI_MODEL` = `gpt-4o-mini`

chunks.title: 4. Deploy the Function
chunks.text:
### 4. Deploy the Function

```bash
supabase functions deploy chat-assistant
```

chunks.title: 5. Test It
chunks.text:
### 5. Test It

The app will automatically use the Edge Function. To test manually:

```bash
supabase functions serve chat-assistant
```

Then test with curl (replace `YOUR_ANON_KEY`):

```bash
curl -i --location --request POST 'http://localhost:54321/functions/v1/chat-assistant' \
  --header 'Authorization: Bearer YOUR_ANON_KEY' \
  --header 'Content-Type: application/json' \
  --data '{
    "userMessage": "How do credits work?",
    "history": []
  }'
```

chunks.title: How It Works
chunks.text:
## How It Works

1. **Mobile App** calls `supabase.functions.invoke("chat-assistant", {...})`
2. **Edge Function**:
   - Verifies user authentication
   - Retrieves `OPENAI_API_KEY` from Supabase secrets
   - Calls OpenAI API with user message + KB context
   - Returns formatted response
3. **Mobile App** displays the response with Markdown rendering

chunks.title: Fallback Behavior
chunks.text:
## Fallback Behavior

If the Edge Function is unavailable, the app will:
- Try direct OpenAI (if `EXPO_PUBLIC_OPENAI_API_KEY` is set locally)
- Show a helpful error message asking user to contact support

chunks.title: Troubleshooting
chunks.text: ## Troubleshooting

chunks.title: Function Not Found (404)
chunks.text:
### Function Not Found (404)
- Ensure you've deployed: `supabase functions deploy chat-assistant`
- Check function name matches exactly: `chat-assistant`

chunks.title: Unauthorized (401)
chunks.text:
### Unauthorized (401)
- User must be logged in
- Check that Authorization header is being sent from the app

chunks.title: Service Unavailable (503)
chunks.text:
### Service Unavailable (503)
- Verify `OPENAI_API_KEY` is set in Supabase secrets
- Check Dashboard ‚Üí Edge Functions ‚Üí Secrets

chunks.title: Internal Server Error (500)
chunks.text:
### Internal Server Error (500)
- Check Edge Function logs in Supabase Dashboard
- Verify OpenAI API key is valid and has credits
- Check function logs: `supabase functions logs chat-assistant`

chunks.title: Local Development
chunks.text:
## Local Development

For local development, you can temporarily use direct OpenAI:

1. Set `USE_EDGE_FUNCTION = false` in `lib/aiChat.js`
2. Set `EXPO_PUBLIC_OPENAI_API_KEY` in your `.env` file
3. Restart the dev server

**‚ö†Ô∏è Never commit API keys to git!**

chunks.title: Production Checklist
chunks.text:
## Production Checklist

- [ ] Edge Function deployed: `supabase functions deploy chat-assistant`
- [ ] `OPENAI_API_KEY` set in Supabase secrets
- [ ] `USE_EDGE_FUNCTION = true` in `lib/aiChat.js`
- [ ] Tested with real user authentication
- [ ] Error handling verified
- [ ] Rate limiting considered (if needed)

chunks.title: Security Notes
chunks.text:
## Security Notes

- ‚úÖ API key is never exposed to client code
- ‚úÖ Function requires authenticated users
- ‚úÖ CORS is properly configured
- ‚úÖ Errors don't leak sensitive information

chunks.title: Next Steps
chunks.text:
## Next Steps

- Consider adding rate limiting per user
- Add usage analytics/tracking
- Set up monitoring/alerts for function errors
- Consider caching common responses

chunks.title: Token Registration
chunks.text:
### Token Registration
1. App starts and calls `setupPushNotifications()`
2. Requests notification permissions from user
3. Gets Expo push token from device
4. Stores token in Supabase `user_expo_tokens` table
5. Sets up notification listeners

chunks.title: Sending Notifications
chunks.text:
### Sending Notifications
1. When application status changes (approved/rejected)
2. `sendApplicationStatusNotification()` is called
3. Creates in-app notification in database
4. Sends push notification via Expo Push API
5. User receives notification on device

chunks.title: `user_expo_tokens` Table
chunks.text:
### `user_expo_tokens` Table
```sql
CREATE TABLE user_expo_tokens (
  id UUID DEFAULT gen_random_uuid() PRIMARY KEY,
  user_id UUID REFERENCES user_profiles(id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
  expo_token TEXT NOT NULL,
  device_id TEXT,
  platform TEXT CHECK (platform IN ('ios', 'android', 'web')),
  created_at TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE DEFAULT NOW(),
  updated_at TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE DEFAULT NOW()
);
```

chunks.title: `notifications` Table (if not exists)
chunks.text:
### `notifications` Table (if not exists)
```sql
CREATE TABLE notifications (
  id UUID DEFAULT gen_random_uuid() PRIMARY KEY,
  user_id UUID REFERENCES user_profiles(id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
  title TEXT NOT NULL,
  message TEXT NOT NULL,
  type TEXT NOT NULL,
  related_id TEXT,
  is_read BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE,
  created_at TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE DEFAULT NOW()
);
```

chunks.title: Common Issues:
chunks.text:
### Common Issues:

1. **"No Expo token found"**
   - User hasn't granted notification permissions
   - Token registration failed
   - User is not logged in

2. **Notifications not appearing**
   - Check if using physical device (not simulator)
   - Verify notification permissions are granted
   - Check Expo push token is valid

3. **Database errors**
   - Ensure `user_expo_tokens` table exists
   - Check user_id foreign key constraints
   - Verify Supabase connection

chunks.text:

chunks.text: # Remote Controls Fixes Applied

chunks.title: Summary
chunks.text:
## Summary
This document outlines all the fixes applied to resolve iOS lock screen remote control issues (play, pause, rewind, fast forward, scrub not working).

chunks.title: Issues Identified and Fixed
chunks.text: ## Issues Identified and Fixed

chunks.title: 1. ‚úÖ Redundant `setupPlayer()` Call
chunks.text:
### 1. ‚úÖ Redundant `setupPlayer()` Call
**Problem:**
- `App.js` was calling `trackPlayer.setupPlayer()` directly
- Then `trackPlayer.playTrack()` also calls `setupPlayer()` internally
- This double initialization could cause timing issues or race conditions

**Fix:**
- Removed the redundant `setupPlayer()` call from `App.js`
- `playTrack()` now handles initialization internally
- Ensures single, consistent initialization path

**File:** `App.js` (line ~1009)

---

chunks.title: 2. ‚úÖ Audio Session Configuration Conflict
chunks.text:
### 2. ‚úÖ Audio Session Configuration Conflict
**Problem:**
- `app.json` had `AVAudioSessionCategory: "playback"` set
- TrackPlayer also sets this via `iosCategory: "playback"` in `updateOptions()`
- Even though they match, having both can cause timing conflicts where iOS applies app.json settings first, then TrackPlayer tries to override

**Fix:**
- Removed `AVAudioSessionCategory` and `AVAudioSessionMode` from `app.json`
- TrackPlayer now exclusively manages audio session configuration
- Added comment explaining why these are not set in app.json

**File:** `app.json` (lines 25-26)

---

chunks.title: 3. ‚úÖ Insufficient Delay After Service Registration
chunks.text:
### 3. ‚úÖ Insufficient Delay After Service Registration
**Problem:**
- Service function runs synchronously in JavaScript
- Native bridge needs time to process event listener registrations
- 100ms delay was too short for native bridge to fully process everything

**Fix:**
- Increased delay from 100ms to 250ms after `setupPlayer()` completes
- Gives native bridge more time to process service registration
- Ensures event listeners are fully registered before `updateOptions()` is called

**File:** `src/audio/player.js` (line ~89)

---

chunks.title: 4. ‚úÖ Combined `updateOptions()` Calls
chunks.text:
### 4. ‚úÖ Combined `updateOptions()` Calls
**Problem:**
- `updateOptions()` was being called twice:
  1. First with capabilities
  2. Then with `progressUpdateEventInterval`
- Second call might overwrite or conflict with first call

**Fix:**
- Combined both calls into a single `updateOptions()` call
- All options (capabilities, jumpInterval, progressUpdateEventInterval, iosCategory) set together
- Ensures consistent configuration

**File:** `src/audio/player.js` (lines 99-147)

---

chunks.title: 5. ‚úÖ Enhanced Error Handling
chunks.text:
### 5. ‚úÖ Enhanced Error Handling
**Problem:**
- `updateOptions()` failures were not being caught
- Silent failures could prevent native handlers from being registered

**Fix:**
- Added comprehensive try-catch around `updateOptions()`
- Detailed error logging to identify registration failures
- Logs capability counts and configuration details

**File:** `src/audio/player.js` (lines 102-147)

---

chunks.title: 6. ‚úÖ Improved Service Logging
chunks.text:
### 6. ‚úÖ Improved Service Logging
**Problem:**
- Service function completion wasn't clearly logged
- Difficult to verify service actually ran

**Fix:**
- Enhanced logging in service function completion
- Clear messages indicating synchronous completion
- Explicit confirmation that event listeners are registered

**File:** `src/audio/playbackService.js` (lines 315-347)

---

chunks.text:

   - Service is registered before React mounts

2. **Service Execution:**
   - `[SERVICE]` logs appear when audio starts playing
   - All 8 event handlers are registered synchronously

3. **Player Initialization:**

   - 250ms delay ensures native bridge processes service

4. **Remote Control Events:**

chunks.title: 1. **Critical: Initialization Order (FIXED)**
chunks.text:
### 1. **Critical: Initialization Order (FIXED)**

- **Problem**: `updateOptions()` was being called before the playback service finished registering remote event listeners
- **Impact**: iOS wouldn't recognize the app as ready to receive remote control events
- **Fix**: Added 500ms delay after `TrackPlayer.setupPlayer()` to ensure service listeners are registered before capabilities are set
- **Files**: `src/audio/player.js`

chunks.title: 2. **RemoteJumpForward Syntax Error (FIXED)**
chunks.text:
### 2. **RemoteJumpForward Syntax Error (FIXED)**

- **Problem**: Missing `async (event) =>` wrapper in `RemoteJumpForward` event listener
- **Impact**: Syntax error preventing proper jump forward functionality
- **Fix**: Added proper async function wrapper
- **Files**: `src/audio/playbackService.js`

chunks.title: 3. **RemoteSeek Error Handling (IMPROVED)**
chunks.text:
### 3. **RemoteSeek Error Handling (IMPROVED)**

- **Problem**: If `onSeek` callback errored, the entire seek operation would fail
- **Impact**: Remote seek might appear to fail even though TrackPlayer seek succeeded
- **Fix**: Wrapped callback in try-catch so callback errors don't prevent successful seeks
- **Files**: `src/audio/playbackService.js`

- **Impact**: Unnecessary delays slowing down playback initialization
- **Fix**: Centralized delay in `setupPlayer()` and removed redundant delays
- **Files**: `App.js`, `src/audio/player.js`

chunks.title: Remote Control Event Routing Issues
chunks.text: # Remote Control Event Routing Issues

chunks.title: Problem
chunks.text:
## Problem
iOS lock screen shows artwork and track info, but buttons (play, pause, rewind, fast forward, scrub) don't respond.

chunks.title: Root Causes Identified
chunks.text: ## Root Causes Identified

chunks.title: ‚úÖ Issue 1: Service Registration Pattern (FIXED)
‚ö†Ô∏è Issue 2: Audio Session Category Conflict (POTENTIAL)
chunks.text:
### ‚ö†Ô∏è Issue 2: Audio Session Category Conflict (POTENTIAL)

**Problem:**
Both `app.json` and TrackPlayer set the audio session category:
- `app.json`: `AVAudioSessionCategory: "playback"`
- TrackPlayer: `iosCategory: "playback"` in `updateOptions()`

**Why this could fail:**
- iOS might apply app.json settings first
- TrackPlayer tries to override, but if audio is already playing, iOS might reject the change
- This could prevent remote control events from being routed correctly

**Potential Fix:**
Remove `AVAudioSessionCategory` from `app.json` and let TrackPlayer manage it exclusively:
```json
// app.json - REMOVE these lines:
"AVAudioSessionCategory": "playback",
"AVAudioSessionMode": "default",
```

**Status:** ‚ö†Ô∏è Not yet tested - may not be necessary

---

chunks.title: ‚ö†Ô∏è Issue 3: TrackPlayer State Not Ready
chunks.text:
### ‚ö†Ô∏è Issue 3: TrackPlayer State Not Ready

**Problem:**
Remote control events might arrive before TrackPlayer has a track loaded or is in a ready state.

**Why this could fail:**
- Handlers call `TrackPlayer.play()`, `TrackPlayer.pause()`, etc.
- If TrackPlayer isn't initialized or has no track, these calls might fail silently
- iOS might stop routing events if handlers fail repeatedly

**Current Protection:**
Handlers now verify TrackPlayer is ready:
```javascript
if (!TrackPlayer || typeof TrackPlayer.getState !== "function") {
  console.error("‚ùå [REMOTE] TrackPlayer not ready");
  return;
}
```

**Status:** ‚úÖ Protected with error handling

---

chunks.title: ‚ö†Ô∏è Issue 4: Service Function Execution Context
‚ö†Ô∏è Issue 5: Timing - Handlers Registered After Capabilities
chunks.text:
### ‚ö†Ô∏è Issue 5: Timing - Handlers Registered After Capabilities

**Problem:**
If capabilities are set before handlers are registered, iOS might not route events.

**Why this could fail:**
- iOS checks for handlers when capabilities are set
- If handlers aren't registered yet, iOS might disable remote controls
- Even if handlers are registered later, iOS might not re-enable them

**Current Protection:**
500ms delay after `setupPlayer()` before setting capabilities:
```javascript
await TrackPlayer.setupPlayer();
await new Promise((resolve) => setTimeout(resolve, 500));
await TrackPlayer.updateOptions({ capabilities, ... });
```

**Status:** ‚úÖ Protected with delay

---

chunks.title: ‚ö†Ô∏è Issue 6: Background Modes Not Enabled
chunks.text:
### ‚ö†Ô∏è Issue 6: Background Modes Not Enabled

**Problem:**
If `UIBackgroundModes: ["audio"]` is missing, iOS won't allow background playback or remote controls.

**Current Status:**
‚úÖ Already configured in `app.json`:
```json
"UIBackgroundModes": ["audio"]
```

---

chunks.title: Debugging Checklist
chunks.text:
## Debugging Checklist

When remote controls don't work, check these in order:

1. **Service Registration**
   - Look for `[STARTUP]` logs showing service registered
   - Should see: `‚úÖ‚úÖ‚úÖ [STARTUP] Playback service registered successfully`

2. **Service Execution**
   - Look for `[SERVICE]` logs when audio starts playing
   - Should see: `üéµ [SERVICE] Playback service function called by TrackPlayer`
   - Should see: `‚úÖ‚úÖ‚úÖ [SERVICE] ALL remote control handlers registered successfully`

3. **Handler Calls**
   - When you press buttons, look for `[REMOTE]` logs
   - Should see: `üîµüîµüîµ [REMOTE] PLAY button pressed`
   - If you DON'T see these logs ‚Üí iOS isn't routing events (service registration issue)
   - If you DO see these logs but playback doesn't change ‚Üí TrackPlayer methods are failing

4. **TrackPlayer State**
   - Check if TrackPlayer has a track loaded: `TrackPlayer.getActiveTrack()`
   - Check if TrackPlayer is playing: `TrackPlayer.getState()`
   - Remote controls won't work if no track is loaded

5. **Audio Session**
   - Check for audio session errors in device logs
   - Look for: `could not fetch audio session category`
   - This indicates a conflict between app.json and

chunks.title: Debugging Checklist
chunks.text:
TrackPlayer

6. **Capabilities**
   - Verify capabilities are set: Look for `[PLAYER]` logs
   - Should see: `‚úÖ‚úÖ‚úÖ [PLAYER] Capabilities configured`

chunks.title: Registration Pattern
Service Export Pattern
Verification Checklist
chunks.text: ## Verification Checklist

chunks.title: ‚úÖ 1. Service Registration
chunks.text:
### ‚úÖ 1. Service Registration

- [x] Called at app startup (before React mounts)
- [x] Called before any audio plays
- [x] Wrapped in try-catch for graceful fallback
- [x] Logs registration success

chunks.title: ‚úÖ 2. Service Export
chunks.text:
### ‚úÖ 2. Service Export

- [x] Uses `module.exports = async function playbackService()`
- [x] Function is exported correctly (not module object)
- [x] Service function will be called by TrackPlayer when `setupPlayer()` is invoked

chunks.title: ‚úÖ 3. Registration Pattern
chunks.text:
### ‚úÖ 3. Registration Pattern

- [x] `registerPlaybackService(() => require("./src/audio/playbackService"))`
- [x] Returns the service function (not module object)
- [x] Includes verification logging

chunks.title: How It Works
chunks.text:
## How It Works

1. **App Starts** ‚Üí `index.js` executes
2. **Service Registered** ‚Üí `TrackPlayer.registerPlaybackService()` called
3. **Service Function Stored** ‚Üí TrackPlayer stores reference to service function
4. **setupPlayer() Called** ‚Üí When `TrackPlayer.setupPlayer()` is invoked later
5. **Service Function Executed** ‚Üí TrackPlayer calls the registered service function
6. **Event Handlers Registered** ‚Üí Service function registers all remote event listeners
7. **iOS Routes Events** ‚Üí iOS sends remote control events to registered handlers

chunks.title: Debugging
chunks.text: ## Debugging

chunks.title: Check Registration Logs
chunks.text:
### Check Registration Logs

Look for `[STARTUP]` logs in Console:

```
‚úÖ‚úÖ‚úÖ [STARTUP] Registering playback service for iOS remote controls...
‚úÖ‚úÖ‚úÖ [STARTUP] Service function correctly loaded (type: function)
‚úÖ‚úÖ‚úÖ [STARTUP] Playback service registered successfully
```

chunks.title: Check Service Execution Logs
chunks.text:
### Check Service Execution Logs

Look for `[SERVICE]` logs (appears when `setupPlayer()` is called):

```
üéµ [SERVICE] Playback service function called by TrackPlayer
‚úÖ [SERVICE] TrackPlayer is ready - registering remote control handlers
‚úÖ‚úÖ‚úÖ [SERVICE] ALL remote control handlers registered successfully
```

chunks.title: If Service Not Registered
chunks.text:
### If Service Not Registered

- Check Console for `‚ö†Ô∏è [STARTUP] Track player not available`
- This is expected in Expo Go - need native build
- Rebuild with EAS: `eas build --platform ios`

chunks.title: If Service Function Not Called
chunks.text:
### If Service Function Not Called

- Check that `TrackPlayer.setupPlayer()` is being called
- Check for `[PLAYER]` logs showing setup completed
- Service function is called automatically when `setupPlayer()` runs

chunks.text: ## Potential Issues (All Resolved)

chunks.title: ‚úÖ Issue 1: Mixed Export Pattern
chunks.text:
### ‚úÖ Issue 1: Mixed Export Pattern

**Problem:** Using both `module.exports` and `export function`
**Status:** ‚úÖ OK - Both work together, CommonJS for service, ES6 for helpers

chunks.title: ‚úÖ Issue 2: Service Function Return
chunks.text:
### ‚úÖ Issue 2: Service Function Return

**Problem:** Need to ensure `require()` returns function, not module object
**Status:** ‚úÖ Verified - `module.exports = function()` means `require()` returns function directly

chunks.title: ‚úÖ Issue 3: Registration Timing
chunks.text:
### ‚úÖ Issue 3: Registration Timing

**Problem:** Service must be registered before React mounts
**Status:** ‚úÖ Correct - Registration happens at top level of `index.js`

chunks.title: Summary
chunks.text:
## Summary

‚úÖ **Service registration is correct**
‚úÖ **Export pattern is correct**
‚úÖ **Registration timing is correct**
‚úÖ **Error handling is in place**
‚úÖ **Logging is comprehensive**

The service registration should work. If remote controls still don't work, the issue is likely:

- Service function not being called (check `[SERVICE]` logs)
- Event handlers not being registered (check `[SERVICE]` logs)
- Capabilities not set (check `[PLAYER]` logs)
- Events not reaching handlers (check `[REMOTE]` logs)

-- Allow authenticated users to upload files
CREATE POLICY "Authenticated users can upload files" ON storage.objects
  FOR INSERT TO authenticated
  WITH CHECK (bucket_id IN ('mixes', 'message-media', 'profile-images'));

-- Allow public access to files
CREATE POLICY "Public files are viewable" ON storage.objects
  FOR SELECT TO public
  USING (bucket_id IN ('mixes', 'message-media', 'profile-images'));

chunks.title: Enables Row Level Security (RLS)
chunks.text:

- Prevents unauthorized access to your data
- Ensures users can only access their own data

chunks.title: Creates Security Policies
chunks.text:

chunks.text:

- Authenticated users get full access to their data
- Anonymous users get read-only access to public data
- Prevents unauthorized data modification

chunks.title: üîç The Problem
chunks.text:
## üîç The Problem

JavaScript `console.log()` statements don't appear in iOS system logs. The Console.app logs you're seeing are from iOS system daemons (SpringBoard, runningboardd, etc.), not your React Native JavaScript code.

---

chunks.title: ‚úÖ Solution 1: In-App Alerts (Easiest - Already Implemented)

chunks.title: Step 2: Open Console.app on Mac
chunks.text:

chunks.text:

chunks.title: üêõ Understanding What You Shared
chunks.text:
## üêõ Understanding What You Shared

The logs you pasted are **iOS system logs**, showing:

```
SpringBoard    - UI management
runningboardd  - Process management
backboardd     - Input/keyboard handling
cameracaptured - Camera/display monitoring
RHOOD          - Your app's native layer (not JS console.logs)
```

These are useful for:

- ‚ùå Debugging React Native JavaScript
- ‚úÖ Debugging native iOS issues
- ‚úÖ Seeing app lifecycle events
- ‚úÖ Diagnosing system-level problems

**To see your JavaScript console.logs**, you need Console.app filtered to your app or the in-app alerts.

chunks.title: Method 1: Device Logs (Easiest)
chunks.text:
### Method 1: Device Logs (Easiest)

#### On Mac:

1. **Connect iPhone to Mac via USB** (required for Console access)
2. **Open Console.app** (Applications ‚Üí Utilities ‚Üí Console)
3. **Select your device** from left sidebar
4. **Filter logs** by typing in search: `[REMOTE]` or `[SERVICE]`

#### On iPhone:

1. **Start audio playback** in the app
2. **Lock the device** (press power button)
3. **Press Play/Pause** on lock screen
4. **Check Mac Console** - you should see:
   ```
   üîµüîµüîµ [REMOTE] PLAY button pressed on lock screen/Control Center
   ‚úÖ‚úÖ‚úÖ [REMOTE] Play executed successfully
   ```

chunks.title: Method 2: React Native Debugger / Metro Logs
chunks.text:
### Method 2: React Native Debugger / Metro Logs

If you're running the app with Metro bundler connected:

1. **Run app with Metro** (if in development mode)
2. **Check terminal** where Metro is running
3. **Look for** `[REMOTE]`, `[SERVICE]`, `[PLAYER]` logs

**Note**: Metro logs work best in development builds. Production TestFlight builds typically don't connect to Metro.

chunks.title: Method 3: Xcode Device Console
chunks.text:
### Method 3: Xcode Device Console

1. **Open Xcode**
2. **Window ‚Üí Devices and Simulators**
3. **Select your connected iPhone**
4. **Click "Open Console"** button
5. **Filter by**: `[REMOTE]` or your app's bundle ID

chunks.title: What to Look For
chunks.text: ## What to Look For

chunks.title: ‚úÖ Good Signs (Everything Working)
chunks.text:
### ‚úÖ Good Signs (Everything Working)

**At App Startup:**

```
‚úÖ‚úÖ‚úÖ [STARTUP] Registering playback service for iOS remote controls...
‚úÖ‚úÖ‚úÖ [STARTUP] Playback service registered successfully
```

**When Audio Plays:**

```
üéµ [SERVICE] Playback service function called by TrackPlayer
‚úÖ‚úÖ‚úÖ [SERVICE] ALL remote control handlers registered successfully
‚úÖ‚úÖ‚úÖ [PLAYER] Capabilities configured - iOS buttons should now be enabled
```

**When You Press Lock Screen Button:**

```
üîµüîµüîµ [REMOTE] PLAY button pressed on lock screen/Control Center
‚úÖ‚úÖ‚úÖ [REMOTE] Play executed successfully
```

chunks.title: ‚ùå Bad Signs (Issues)
chunks.text:
### ‚ùå Bad Signs (Issues)

**No `[STARTUP]` logs:**

- Service not registering
- Check that `react-native-track-player` is properly installed
- Rebuild required

**No `[SERVICE]` logs:**

- Service function not being called
- Check that `TrackPlayer.setupPlayer()` is being called
- Verify audio playback actually starts

**No `[REMOTE]` logs when pressing buttons:**

- Events not reaching handlers
- Possible causes:
  - Service not registered correctly
  - Capabilities not set
  - Hot reload didn't re-register service ‚Üí **Cold start app**
  - Wrong build (Expo Go won't work)

**`[REMOTE]` logs appear but audio doesn't change:**

- TrackPlayer methods failing
- Check for error logs: `‚ùå‚ùå‚ùå [REMOTE] ... error:`
- Possible state mismatch or queue issues

chunks.title: React Native Track Player Setup
chunks.text:
# React Native Track Player Setup

This document explains the setup for `react-native-track-player` on iOS for native lock screen and Control Center media controls.

chunks.title: Configuration
chunks.text: ## Configuration

chunks.title: app.json
chunks.text:
### app.json

The `react-native-track-player` config plugin is **not included** in `app.json` because:

1. Background audio modes are already configured via `UIBackgroundModes: ["audio"]`
2. The library doesn't require a config plugin - it works with native modules directly
3. Removing it prevents module resolution errors during EAS builds

The necessary iOS configuration is already present:

- `UIBackgroundModes: ["audio"]` - enables background audio playback
- `AVAudioSessionCategory: "playback"` - sets audio session category

chunks.title: Building
chunks.text: ## Building

chunks.title: For Development/Testing
chunks.text:
### For Development/Testing

Before building, you need to generate native projects:

```bash

chunks.title: Generate iOS native project
chunks.text:
# Generate iOS native project
npx expo prebuild --platform ios
```

chunks.title: EAS Build (Recommended)
chunks.text:
### EAS Build (Recommended)

If you encounter CocoaPods dependency conflicts during EAS builds, clear the cache:

```bash

chunks.title: Build with cleared cache (fixes pod dependency issues)
chunks.text:
# Build with cleared cache (fixes pod dependency issues)
eas build -p ios --profile development --clear-cache
```

Or build without cache clearing (faster, but may fail if dependencies changed):

```bash
eas build -p ios --profile development
```

chunks.title: Local Build
chunks.text:
### Local Build

To test locally:

```bash
npx expo run:ios
```

chunks.title: Important Notes
chunks.text:
### Important Notes

1. **Expo Go won't work**: `react-native-track-player` requires native modules and only works with development builds or production builds via EAS/TestFlight.

2. **Native setup**: After running `npx expo prebuild`, the native iOS project will be generated in the `ios/` directory. The library's native code will be automatically linked.

3. **Background audio**: The app already has `UIBackgroundModes: ["audio"]` configured, which is required for lock screen controls.

chunks.title: How It Works
chunks.text: ## How It Works

chunks.title: iOS Implementation
chunks.text:
### iOS Implementation

- Uses `react-native-track-player` for iOS playback
- Automatically displays native MPNowPlayingInfoCenter controls on lock screen and Control Center
- Handles remote commands (AirPods, car, lock screen buttons)
- Requires no manual notification setup - iOS handles it natively

chunks.title: Android Implementation
chunks.text:
### Android Implementation

- Continues using `expo-av` with MediaStyle notifications
- No changes to existing Android behavior

chunks.title: Files
chunks.text:
## Files

- `src/audio/player.js` - Player initialization and control functions
- `src/audio/playbackService.js` - Background service for remote commands
- `index.js` - Registers the playback service at app startup
- `App.js` - Routes iOS to track-player, Android to expo-av

chunks.title: Testing
chunks.text:
## Testing

1. Build a development or production build (not Expo Go)
2. Install on a physical iOS device
3. Play audio from the app
4. Lock the device - you should see:
   - Track artwork (if provided)
   - Title and artist
   - Progress bar (if duration is set)
   - Play/pause, next, previous, and seek controls
5. Test remote controls:
   - AirPods play/pause buttons
   - Car media controls
   - Lock screen controls

chunks.title: Troubleshooting
chunks.text: ## Troubleshooting

chunks.title: "Track player initialization failed"
chunks.text:
### "Track player initialization failed"

- Make sure you're not running in Expo Go
- Build a development build: `eas build -p ios --profile development`
- Check console logs for specific errors

chunks.title: Lock screen controls not appearing
chunks.text:
### Lock screen controls not appearing

- Verify audio is actually playing
- Check that `UIBackgroundModes: ["audio"]` is in app.json
- Ensure artwork URLs are https and accessible
- Test on a real device (not simulator)

chunks.title: CocoaPods dependency conflicts during EAS build
chunks.text:
### CocoaPods dependency conflicts during EAS build

If you see errors like "Compatible versions of some pods could not be resolved":

1. **Clear EAS cache and rebuild:**

   ```bash
   eas build -p ios --profile development --clear-cache
   ```

2. **Or manually clear cache on EAS:**

   - Go to the build page in Expo dashboard
   - Click "Clear cache and retry build"

3. **Verify local pods work:**
   ```bash
   cd ios && pod install
   ```
   If this works locally, the issue is likely just the EAS cache.

chunks.title: Module resolution errors during build
chunks.text:
### Module resolution errors during build

- Removed the config plugin from app.json (already done)
- Clean and rebuild: `rm -rf node_modules/.cache && npm install`

chunks.title: Troubleshooting Lock Screen Audio Controls
chunks.text: # Troubleshooting Lock Screen Audio Controls

chunks.title: Issue: No audio player showing on lock screen
chunks.text: ## Issue: No audio player showing on lock screen

chunks.title: Quick Diagnostic Checklist
chunks.text:
### Quick Diagnostic Checklist

1. **Check if you're using Expo Go:**

   - ‚ùå Expo Go does NOT support custom native modules
   - ‚úÖ You MUST use a development build or TestFlight build

2. **Check console logs when playing audio:**
   Look for these messages:

   - `‚úÖ NowPlayingInfo native module found!` - Module is loaded
   - `‚ö†Ô∏è NowPlayingInfo native module not found` - Module not loaded (this is the problem)
   - `üéµ Setting Now Playing info:` - Metadata being set
   - `‚úÖ Now Playing info set successfully!` - Metadata set successfully

3. **Verify native module setup:**

   ```bash
   # Check if iOS project exists
   ls ios/

   # Check if native files exist
   ls ios/RHOODApp/NowPlayingInfoModule.*
   ```

chunks.title: Common Causes & Solutions
chunks.text:
### Common Causes & Solutions

#### Cause 1: Using Expo Go

**Solution:** Build a development build:

```bash

chunks.title: Generate iOS native project
chunks.text:
# Generate iOS native project
npx expo prebuild --platform ios

chunks.title: Build development client
chunks.text:
# Build development client
npx expo run:ios
```

#### Cause 2: Native files not added to Xcode

**Symptoms:** Console shows "NowPlayingInfo native module not found"

**Solution:**

1. Open `ios/RHOODApp.xcworkspace` in Xcode
2. Add the native module files to the project (see `docs/IOS_NOW_PLAYING_SETUP.md`)
3. Set bridging header path
4. Add MediaPlayer framework
5. Rebuild

#### Cause 3: Audio session not configured correctly

**Solution:** The audio mode should already be configured, but verify:

- `staysActiveInBackground: true` is set
- Audio is actually playing when you lock the screen

#### Cause 4: iOS Simulator limitations

**Solution:** Test on a real iOS device. Lock screen controls may not work reliably in the simulator.

chunks.title: Testing Steps
chunks.text:
### Testing Steps

1. **Play audio in the app**
2. **Check console logs** - should see Now Playing info being set
3. **Lock the device** (don't just turn off screen - actually lock it)
4. **Wake the lock screen** - audio player should appear

chunks.title: If Still Not Working
chunks.text:
### If Still Not Working

1. Check that audio is actually playing:

   - Can you hear the audio?
   - Is the play button showing as playing in the app?

2. Verify audio session:

   ```javascript
   // In console, check:
   Audio.getAudioModeAsync().then(console.log);
   // Should show: staysActiveInBackground: true
   ```

3. Try restarting the app after making changes

4. Clean build:
   ```bash
   # In Xcode: Product ‚Üí Clean Build Folder (Shift+Cmd+K)
   npx expo run:ios
   ```

chunks.title: Expected Console Output (When Working)
chunks.text:
### Expected Console Output (When Working)

```
‚úÖ NowPlayingInfo native module found!
‚úÖ Audio mode configured for native lock screen controls
üéµ Setting Now Playing info: { title: '...', artist: '...', ... }
‚úÖ Now Playing info set successfully!
```

chunks.title: Expected Console Output (When NOT Working)
chunks.text:
### Expected Console Output (When NOT Working)

```
‚ö†Ô∏è NowPlayingInfo native module not found. Available modules: [...]
‚ö†Ô∏è NowPlayingInfo native module not available. This requires a development build...
‚ö†Ô∏è Make sure you've:
1. Run 'npx expo prebuild --platform ios'
2. Added the native files to Xcode project
3. Built a development build (not Expo Go)
```

chunks.title: Solution: Fix EAS Build CocoaPods Error
chunks.text: # Solution: Fix EAS Build CocoaPods Error

chunks.title: The Problem
chunks.text:
## The Problem

EAS builds are failing with:

```
Compatible versions of some pods could not be resolved.
```

**Root Cause**: EAS is using a cached `Podfile.lock` from BEFORE `react-native-track-player` was added to the project.

chunks.title: Why This Happens
chunks.text:
## Why This Happens

1. You added `react-native-track-player`
2. EAS has a cached `Podfile.lock` from an older build (before the new dependency)
3. EAS tries to resolve pods using the old cached version
4. The old version doesn't include `react-native-track-player` or `SwiftAudioEx`
5. Pod resolution fails

chunks.title: The Solution (MUST DO THIS)
chunks.text: ## The Solution (MUST DO THIS)

chunks.title: Step 1: Verify Local Installation Works
chunks.text:
### Step 1: Verify Local Installation Works

```bash
cd ios && pod install
```

If this works locally (it should), the problem is definitely EAS cache.

chunks.title: Step 2: Build with --clear-cache Flag
chunks.text:
### Step 2: Build with --clear-cache Flag

**You MUST use this command:**

```bash
eas build -p ios --profile development --clear-cache
```

The `--clear-cache` flag is **critical** - it tells EAS to:

- Ignore cached `Podfile.lock`
- Use your committed `Podfile.lock` from git
- Rebuild pods fresh

chunks.title: Step 3: Verify Podfile.lock is Committed
chunks.text:
### Step 3: Verify Podfile.lock is Committed

Make sure `ios/Podfile.lock` is in git:

```bash
git status ios/Podfile.lock
```

If it shows changes, commit it:

```bash
git add ios/Podfile.lock
git commit -m "Update Podfile.lock with react-native-track-player"
```

chunks.title: What's Already Fixed
chunks.text:
## What's Already Fixed

1. ‚úÖ `Podfile.lock` is committed with `react-native-track-player` dependencies
2. ‚úÖ `eas.json` updated to exclude `ios/Pods` from caching
3. ‚úÖ Local pod installation verified working

chunks.title: Important Notes
chunks.text:
## Important Notes

- **You MUST use `--clear-cache`** for the FIRST build after adding a native module
- After this first successful build, subsequent builds should work normally
- If you skip `--clear-cache`, EAS will keep using the old cached `Podfile.lock`

chunks.title: Quick Command Reference
chunks.text:
## Quick Command Reference

```bash

chunks.title: Check if local pods work
chunks.text:
# Check if local pods work
cd ios && pod install

chunks.title: Build with cleared cache (DO THIS)
chunks.text:
# Build with cleared cache (DO THIS)
eas build -p ios --profile development --clear-cache

chunks.title: After first successful build, this should work:
chunks.text:
# After first successful build, this should work:
eas build -p ios --profile development
```

chunks.title: Still Having Issues?
chunks.text:
## Still Having Issues?

If `--clear-cache` doesn't work:

1. Check the actual EAS build logs URL for specific pod conflicts
2. Try deleting Podfile.lock from git temporarily:
   ```bash
   git rm --cached ios/Podfile.lock
   git commit -m "Remove Podfile.lock to let EAS generate fresh"
   ```
3. Contact EAS support with the build logs

chunks.text: # EAS Build Instructions - CocoaPods Fix

chunks.title: The Problem
chunks.text:
## The Problem

EAS builds are failing with:

```
Compatible versions of some pods could not be resolved.
```

This happens because EAS cached a `Podfile.lock` from before `react-native-track-player` was added.

chunks.title: The Solution
chunks.text: ## The Solution

chunks.title: Option 1: Clear Cache (Recommended for first build after adding native module)
chunks.text:
### Option 1: Clear Cache (Recommended for first build after adding native module)

```bash
eas build -p ios --profile development --clear-cache
```

chunks.title: Option 2: After Podfile.lock is committed
chunks.text:
### Option 2: After Podfile.lock is committed

Once `ios/Podfile.lock` is committed to git with the correct dependencies, EAS will use the committed version:

```bash

chunks.title: Make sure Podfile.lock is committed
chunks.text:
# Make sure Podfile.lock is committed
git add ios/Podfile.lock
git commit -m "Update Podfile.lock with react-native-track-player"

chunks.title: Then build (cache should work now)

eas build -p ios --profile development
```

chunks.title: What Changed

## What Changed

1. **Committed Podfile.lock**: The updated `Podfile.lock` with `react-native-track-player` dependencies is now in git
2. **Updated eas.json**: Removed `ios/Pods` from cache paths to avoid stale pod installations
3. **Pod Dependencies**: Verified locally - `react-native-track-player (4.1.2)` and `SwiftAudioEx (1.1.0)` install correctly

chunks.title: Step 1: Reload the App
chunks.text:
### Step 1: Reload the App

**Expo Go**: Shake device ‚Üí Tap "Reload"
**Physical Device**: Close app completely, then reopen

chunks.title: Step 2: Test Message Persistence
chunks.text:
### Step 2: Test Message Persistence

1. Navigate to **Connections** tab
2. Tap **Messages** subtab
3. Open chat with Eloka (or any connected user)
4. **Send a test message** (e.g., "Testing 123")
5. **Expected**: Message should appear immediately in chat

**Test Persistence**:

- Navigate back to Connections list
- Re-open the Eloka chat
- **Expected**: Your message should still be there

**Test Real-time**:

- Send another message
- Lock your phone screen
- Unlock and check
- **Expected**: New message should still be visible

chunks.title: Step 3: Test Lock Screen Controls
chunks.text:
### Step 3: Test Lock Screen Controls

1. Navigate to **Listen** screen
2. Play a mix (tap any mix to start playback)
3. **Immediately lock your phone** (press power button)
4. Look at lock screen

**Expected on iOS**:

- Should see album artwork
- Should see track title and artist name
- Should see play/pause button in center
- Should see skip forward/backward buttons
- Scrubbing should work on the timeline

**Expected on Android**:

- Should see media notification
- Should see album artwork (if available)
- Should see track title and artist name
- Should see play/pause, next, previous controls

**Test Lock Screen Actions**:

- Tap play/pause on lock screen
- **Expected**: Audio should pause/resume
- Tap next button (if available)
- **Expected**: Next track should play
- Drag timeline scrubber
- **Expected**: Audio position should change

---

chunks.title: üîç How to Verify Messages Are Working
chunks.text: ## üîç How to Verify Messages Are Working

chunks.title: Step 1: Check Console Logs
chunks.text:
### Step 1: Check Console Logs

When you open a chat, you should see:

```
üì• loadMessages started: { chatType: 'individual', djId: '...', userId: '...' }
üßµ Using thread ID: abc123...
üì® Individual messages loaded: X messages
üìã First message preview: { id: '...', content: '...', sender: '...', timestamp: '...' }
```

If you see:

```
‚ö†Ô∏è NO MESSAGES RETURNED FROM DATABASE
üìã Query details: { threadId: '...', table: 'messages', filter: '...' }
```

**This means the database query returned empty. Check if messages exist in that thread.**

chunks.title: Step 2: When Sending a Message
chunks.text:
### Step 2: When Sending a Message

After sending, you should see:

```
‚úÖ Individual message sent successfully!
‚úÖ Message data saved to database: { id: '...', thread_id: '...', sender_id: '...', content: '...', created_at: '...' }
```

If you see:

```
‚ùå Error sending individual message
‚ùå Error details: { code: '...', message: '...', hint: '...', details: '...' }
```

**This means the message failed to save. Check RLS policies.**

chunks.title: Step 3: Run SQL Test in Supabase
chunks.text:
### Step 3: Run SQL Test in Supabase

Run `database/test-messages-quick.sql` to verify messages are actually in the database.

chunks.title: üêõ Troubleshooting
chunks.text: ## üêõ Troubleshooting

chunks.title: Messages Not Appearing
chunks.text:
### Messages Not Appearing

**Symptoms**: Chat shows "NO MESSAGES YET" even after sending

**Solutions**:

1. **Check console logs** - Look for the messages above
2. Run `database/test-messages-quick.sql` to verify messages are in database
3. Check app logs for thread ID mismatchesew
4. Verify RLS policies were applied correctly
5. Check that you're testing with an **accepted connection**

chunks.title: Messages Sending But Not Saving
chunks.text:
### Messages Sending But Not Saving

**Symptoms**: Console shows "‚úÖ Individual message sent successfully!" but message disappears

**Solutions**:

1. Check for RLS errors in console logs
2. Verify `database/fix-all-messaging-rls.sql` was run successfully
3. Check that `thread_id` matches in both INSERT and SELECT queries
4. Verify you're logged in as the correct user

chunks.title: Lock Screen Controls Not Showing
chunks.text:
### Lock Screen Controls Not Showing

**Symptoms**: No controls appear when phone is locked during playback

**Solutions**:

1. Verify you're on a **physical device** (lock screen doesn't work in simulator)
2. Check that audio is actually playing before locking
3. Make sure app is not in foreground restrictions mode
4. Try closing and reopening the app after code changes
5. Check logs for "üîí Lock screen controls enabled" message

chunks.title: Messages Not Persisting
chunks.text:
### Messages Not Persisting

**Symptoms**: Messages disappear after navigating away

**Solutions**:

1. Run `database/cleanup-duplicate-threads.sql` to fix thread issues
2. Verify RLS policies allow SELECT operations
3. Check network connection
4. Look for RLS errors in Supabase logs

---

chunks.text:
## üìù Quick Verification SQL

After testing, run `database/test-messages-quick.sql` to see:

- Recent messages
- Messages per thread
- Thread participants

This helps verify messages are being stored correctly.

chunks.title: 2. Check Console Logs When Playing Audio
chunks.text:
### 2. Check Console Logs When Playing Audio

**Good Signs:**
```
üéµ playGlobalAudio called with track: { id: '...', title: '...', ... }
üîÑ Sound created: [object Sound]
üìä Initial sound status: { isLoaded: true, durationMillis: 180000, ... }

```

chunks.title: 3. Common Audio Issues
chunks.text:
### 3. Common Audio Issues

#### Issue: "Audio playback not available in Expo Go"
**Fix**: This is normal in Expo Go. Test on a physical device or EAS build.

#### Issue: "Sound failed to load properly"
**Fix**: 
- Check audio URL is valid
- Verify network connection
- Check if audio file exists in Supabase Storage

#### Issue: Audio plays but no sound
**Fix**:
- Check device volume
- Check if device is in silent mode
- Verify `playsInSilentModeIOS: true` is set in audio mode config

---

chunks.title: üì® Messages Not Sending - Debug Steps
chunks.text: ## üì® Messages Not Sending - Debug Steps

chunks.title: 1. Check Console Logs When Sending
chunks.text:
### 1. Check Console Logs When Sending

**Good Signs:**
```
üì§ Sending message: { chatType: 'individual', userId: '...', ... }
üßµ Using thread ID: abc123...
‚úÖ Individual message sent successfully!
‚úÖ Message data saved to database: { id: '...', thread_id: '...', ... }
üéâ Message sent successfully!
üì® New individual message received: [message data]
```

**Bad Signs:**
```
‚ùå Error sending individual message: [error object]
‚ùå Error details: { code: '42501', message: 'permission denied', ... }
```

chunks.title: 2. Common Message Issues
chunks.text:
### 2. Common Message Issues

#### Issue: "permission denied for table messages"
**Fix**: Run `database/fix-all-messaging-rls.sql` in Supabase SQL Editor

#### Issue: "Invalid input syntax for type uuid"
**Fix**: Check that `user.id` and `djId` are valid UUIDs

#### Issue: Messages send but don't appear
**Fix**: 
- Check console for "üì® New individual message received" - if missing, real-time subscription issue
- Verify thread IDs match between INSERT and SELECT
- Run `database/cleanup-duplicate-threads.sql`

chunks.title: 3. Quick SQL Check
chunks.text:
### 3. Quick SQL Check

Run this in Supabase SQL Editor to see if messages are being saved:

```sql
SELECT * FROM messages 
ORDER BY created_at DESC 
LIMIT 10;
```

If you see messages here but not in app = loading issue
If you don't see messages here = sending issue

---
